1.1.01-001.asw_3: Stopping as a precaution at every crossroads
1.1.01-001.info:
Participation in road traffic requires constant caution and mutual respect. Therefore, defensive drivers expect other road users to make mistakes.

In addition, defensive drivers are prepared not to insist on their rights in order to resolve dangerous situations.
1.1.01-001.text: What should you understand by defensive driving?

1.1.01-002.asw_3: Driving too close behind the vehicle in front
1.1.01-002.info:
Inattentiveness leads to reactions of other road users being recognized late or not at all. A lack of space between cars shortens the time available to react to the behaviour of the vehicle in front of you.

As a rule, the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you must be such that it can be retained even if the vehicle in front of you brakes suddenly.

If you are driving in front of other vehicles you must not brake hard without a compelling reason.
1.1.01-002.text: What can be the causes of rear-end collisions?

1.1.01-101.asw_2: - may switch on the direction indicators too late before turning
1.1.01-101.asw_3: - could stop unexpectedly to ask the way
1.1.01-101.info:
Due to the fact that the number plate is not local, it cannot be ruled out that the driver of the vehicle with the non-local number plate may not have any local knowledge and as a result may make unexpected decisions.

It is possible that the driver of the vehicle with the non-local number plate will brake unexpectedly. He or she could be very late in activating the direction indicators. The vehicle could also stop unexpectedly.
1.1.01-101.text: You are driving in a built-up area behind a vehicle with number plates that are not local. What could happen?

1.1.01-102.asw_1: Stalling the engine in dense traffic
1.1.01-102.asw_2: Vehicles proceeding too slowly for no good reason
1.1.01-102.asw_3: Motor vehicles breaking down because they have run out of fuel
1.1.01-102.info:
Anyone taking part in traffic must behave in such a way that no one else is harmed, endangered or harassed unnecessarily under the circumstances.

Motor vehicles must not drive so slowly that they impede the flow of traffic without good reason. A fuel shortage can be avoided by regularly checking the tank level.

Stalling the engine can be avoided by practicing starting.

1.1.01-103.asw_1: Because it obstructs the flow of traffic
1.1.01-103.asw_2: Because it increases the danger of rear-end collisions
1.1.01-103.asw_3: Because it encourages vehicle drivers behind to overtake dangerously
1.1.01-103.info: Motor vehicles must not drive so slowly that they impede the flow of traffic without good reason. Slow driving increases the risk of rear-end collisions. In addition, it can tempt the driver of the vehicle behind you to overtake your vehicle.
1.1.01-103.text: Why must you not drive extra slowly for no good reason?

1.1.01-107.info: Both heavy eyelids and frequent yawning are typical signs of fatigue. As a result of fatigue, the ability to react can be impaired, increasing the risk of accidents.
1.1.01-107.text: How can you tell that you are getting tired while you are driving?

1.1.01-108.info:
There are many ways in which fatigue has a negative effect on the driver. There is a danger that he or she will fall asleep for a few seconds and thus lose control of his or her vehicle.

There is also a risk of a lack of concentration, which can lead to driving errors.
1.1.01-108.text: What can happen if you ignore signs of tiredness?

1.1.01-109.asw_2: Get out of the car and move around in the fresh air
1.1.01-109.info: Taking breaks help the body to regenerate and can thus help combat fatigue. Exercise in fresh air stimulates the circulation and activates vital functions.
1.1.01-109.text: What should you do if you start feeling tired while driving?

1.1.01-110.info: Fatigue can affect the driver in many ways. There is a risk of dwindling attention, limited perception of traffic events and delayed reactions.
1.1.01-110.text: How does tiredness affect your driving?

1.1.01-111.asw_2: Through failure to maintain suitable speed
1.1.01-111.asw_3: By having lights turned on during day
1.1.01-111.info:
Whether the speed is too high or too low, in both cases there is a risk of dangerous traffic situations. For example, a low speed can motivate other motorists to overtake your vehicle in a dangerous manner.

Driving at too high a speed presents dangers such as leaving too little time to detect dangerous situations.

Depending on their position, vehicles at a standstill are only recognised by other motorists at a late stage, which can lead to collisions or dangerous evasive manoeuvres.
1.1.01-111.text: How could a dangerous situation arise?

1.1.01-112.info:
Both distraction and inattention result in inadequate observation of the road and the traffic situation, presenting the threat of veering off the road. Fatigue presents the same danger.

Perception and reaction can be restricted, and there is also the threat of nodding off for a moment.
1.1.01-112.text: What could cause the vehicle to leave the road?

1.1.02-005.asw_1: They will run onto the zebra crossing without paying attention to traffic
1.1.02-005.asw_2: They will turn around on the zebra crossing for no apparent reason and run back
1.1.02-005.asw_3: They will wait at the curb because they always correctly judge the speed and distance of approaching vehicles
1.1.02-005.info: It is not certain that children will wait until a car stops at the zebra crossing. Instead, they may run across the street at any time. There is also the risk that they might spontaneously turn around on the zebra crossing and run back to where they came from.
1.1.02-005.text: What conduct must you expect of children at zebra crossings?

1.1.02-022.asw_1: - will already start running when the traffic lights in my driving direction change from green to amber
1.1.02-022.asw_2: - will also start running when the light is red because they cannot wait since it's taking them too long
1.1.02-022.asw_3: - will push each other onto the roadway
1.1.02-022.info:
The behaviour of children at a traffic light is difficult to predict. There is a risk that they will already start running across the road while the light is still red because, for example, they may overlook approaching vehicles.

They could also start running at the first sign of a change of traffic light. It is also possible that children may push each other into the road.
1.1.02-022.text: What do you have to reckon with when children are waiting at traffic lights?

1.1.02-023.asw_1: - will move onto the roadway without paying attention
1.1.02-023.asw_2: - will move too far onto the roadway
1.1.02-023.asw_3: - will get off their bicycles and wait until the roadway is clear
1.1.02-023.info:
As soon as a cycle path ends, there is always a risk that cyclists will move onto the road without interruption and continue their journey.

Children riding bicycles may not know or may disobey traffic rules and move into the lane in pairs or ride next to one another.
1.1.02-023.text: A group of children are cycling on a cycle path that ends. What do you have to reckon with?

1.1.02-024-B.asw_1: You may pass on the right-hand side at walking speed provided that passengers are not obstructed and you are sure no-one is endangered
1.1.02-024-B.asw_2: If no-one is obstructed or endangered, you may pass on the right-hand side at a speed faster than walking speed
1.1.02-024-B.asw_3: Passengers must allow moving traffic to pass before boarding
1.1.02-024-B.info: Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even if they are oncoming traffic.
1.1.02-024-B.text: Which statements are correct?<pcaption>(Brake lights on)</pcaption>

1.1.02-026-B.asw_1: - not overtake the bus while it is still moving
1.1.02-026-B.asw_2: - pass the stationary bus at walking speed provided you are sure that passengers are not endangered
1.1.02-026-B.asw_3: - overtake the bus while it is still moving
1.1.02-026-B.info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses approaching a bus stop and with hazard warning lights switched on may not be overtaken.

Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.1.02-026-B.text: What must you heed in this situation?<pcaption>(Hazard warning lights on)</pcaption>

1.1.02-027.asw_1: They may stop on the road
1.1.02-027.asw_2: They may turn round and go back
1.1.02-027.asw_3: They will cross the road slowly
1.1.02-027.info: Crossing the road can be exhausting for elderly people with walking aids. Therefore, it cannot be excluded that they may cross the road slowly or even stop in the middle of the road. They may also turn back at any time due to uncertainty or for other reasons.
1.1.02-027.text: What do you have to reckon with when elderly persons using walking frames cross the road?

1.1.02-028.asw_1: I follow behind the wheelchair until I can overtake it
1.1.02-028.asw_2: I overtake it, leaving plenty of room on the side because the wheelchair may swing out
1.1.02-028.asw_3: I honk the horn to indicate that the person is not behaving correctly
1.1.02-028.info: Even if the person in the wheelchair does not behave in accordance with traffic regulations, caution and consideration are required. Therefore, overtaking is only allowed when a safe possibility arises. Because there is the possibility that a wheelchair user may swerve, overtaking must be carried out at an appropriate lateral distance.
1.1.02-028.text: A person in a wheelchair is travelling along the road although there is a pavement on the right. What do you do?

1.1.02-029.asw_1: I stop and switch on the hazard warning lights
1.1.02-029.asw_2: I get out of the car and help the person in the wheelchair
1.1.02-029.asw_3: I honk the horn and drive around the person
1.1.02-029.info: Due to the unfortunate situation, both the person in the wheelchair and other people may be endangered. This is why you should help the person. By switching on your hazard warning lights, other motorists are warned of the potentially dangerous situation.
1.1.02-029.text: Having crossed the road, a person in a wheelchair cannot get up the curb and onto the pavement. What do you do?

1.1.02-032.info: The white stick indicates that the person is visually impaired. Upon closer inspection, the yellow armband confirms this.
1.1.02-032.text: Who has a severe visual handicap?

1.1.02-039-M.asw_3: continue driving at the same speed
1.1.02-039-M.info: Although the children are not on the road, this could change quickly. It is thus crucial to keep an eye on the children and to be ready to brake.

1.1.02-041-M.asw_1: the children will not get off the road in time
1.1.02-041-M.asw_2: some children will turn around again
1.1.02-041-M.asw_3: all children will wait on the pavement
1.1.02-041-M.info: The children are playing and may not notice the vehicle in time. Even after they have left the road, it is possible that one or more children could turn back to get the ball.
1.1.02-041-M.text: What risks must you be aware of?

1.1.02-042-M.info: It is not certain whether the children have noticed the traffic and will behave appropriately. Therefore, you must reduce your speed and be ready to brake.

1.1.02-043-M.asw_3: drive past at the same speed
1.1.02-043-M.info: Although nobody can be seen, a child could inattentively cross the road to get the ball at any time. Therefore, you must reduce your speed and be ready to brake.

1.1.02-108-B.asw_2: - pass only if you are sure that passengers are not endangered
1.1.02-108-B.info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.1.02-108-B.text: What must you heed in this situation?<pcaption>(Hazard warning lights on)</pcaption>

1.1.02-110-B.asw_1: The bus may be passed in either lane but no faster than at walking speed
1.1.02-110-B.asw_2: Vehicles in both lanes must stop if passengers would otherwise be endangered
1.1.02-110-B.asw_3: The vehicles in the left lane may pass the bus without paying any special attention
1.1.02-110-B.info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.1.02-110-B.text: Which statements are correct in this situation?<pcaption>(Hazard warning lights on)</pcaption>

1.1.02-113.asw_1: Slow down and be ready to brake
1.1.02-113.asw_2: Continue driving as before so as not to impede the traffic behind you
1.1.02-113.asw_3: Sound your horn and continue driving
1.1.02-113.info: A child could enter the road at any time without keeping an eye on the traffic. Therefore, you must reduce your speed and be ready to brake.
1.1.02-113.text: You are approaching children playing on the pavement. How must you behave?

1.1.02-116.asw_3: - may be warned using the horn
1.1.02-116.info:
Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even if they are oncoming traffic.

When passengers are boarding or disembarking, they may only be passed on the right at walking speed and only at such a distance that there is no danger to passengers.

They must not be obstructed either. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.1.02-116.text: The tram has just become stationary at the stop. What is the right course of action?

1.1.03-001.info:
Agricultural machinery can discharge soil, clay and other dirt particles onto the roadway, which is why there is an increased risk of slipping at the junctions of dirt roads.

The same applies to junctions of construction sites. There is a risk of pollution from construction site traffic.
1.1.03-001.text: Where must you particularly reckon with dirt on the roadway and therefore danger of skidding?

1.1.03-002.asw_1: The contact between the tyres and the roadway deteriorates
1.1.03-002.info:
Moisture increases the risk of road traffic accidents in many ways. Vehicles in front can splash water, which impairs visibility.

The moisture between the road surface and the tyres reduces the grip of the tyres, which results in a longer braking distance.
1.1.03-002.text: Why must the safe distance maintained be much greater on a wet roadway than on a dry roadway?

1.1.03-003.asw_2: On stretches of road running through forest
1.1.03-003.asw_3: On frequently used stretches of road
1.1.03-003.info:
Wind and a lack of subsoil cause the road surface on bridges to cool down more quickly, threatening earlier icing of the road.

The same applies to forests, where humidity is often higher and less or no direct sunlight reaches the roadway.
1.1.03-003.text: Where must you especially reckon with ice on the roadway?

1.1.03-102-B.asw_1: The road surface is uneven and road grip varies
1.1.03-102-B.asw_2: A tram might come from the opposite direction
1.1.03-102-B.asw_3: Driving on the tracks is dangerous
1.1.03-102-B.info:
Different road surfaces can have different grip and thus influence the driving stability. Especially on tracks, there is a risk of poorer traction. Cyclists must be particularly careful when crossing the tracks so that they do not lose traction.

At the same time, the tracks mean that a tram can appear from either direction at any time. In particular, motorists about to turn left must keep a close eye on rail traffic.
1.1.03-102-B.text: Why does driving on this stretch of road require greater alertness on the part of the motorist?

1.1.03-104.info:
On icy road sections, grip is reduced. Steering movements, braking and acceleration threaten the driving stability of the vehicle.

As soon as the road surface is no longer icy, such interventions can have an abrupt effect and thus significantly change the behaviour of the vehicle.
1.1.03-104.text: The road is icy for a short distance. What should you avoid here, if possible?

1.1.03-105.asw_1: By carefully applying the brakes at very low speed
1.1.03-105.asw_2: By jerking the steering wheel to the left and right
1.1.03-105.info:
If a road is suspected to be icy, a test should always be carried out with extreme caution to prevent the vehicle from swerving or skidding.

For this purpose, it is possible to brake in a controlled manner at a slow speed after looking into the rear-view mirror.
1.1.03-105.text: While driving, how can you safely check whether the road is icy?

1.1.03-108-B.asw_2: Because the view is obscured by the bend
1.1.03-108-B.asw_3: Because the roadway is made narrower by the wrongly parked car
1.1.03-108-B.info:
The incorrectly parked car makes it difficult to see into and around the bend. In addition, it requires a lane change while driving through a narrow lane at the same time.

The snow provides less grip, which makes steering more difficult and increases braking distance.
1.1.03-108-B.text: Why must you drive with particular caution here?

1.1.03-109.info: The sudden appearance of fog is possible almost everywhere. But in places near bodies of water, such as rivers, moors and lakes, the probability for fog to appear is particularly high.
1.1.03-109.text: Where must you be prepared to encounter sudden fog?

1.1.03-110.asw_1: Adapt your speed in time to visibility conditions
1.1.03-110.asw_2: Increase the distance from the vehicle in front
1.1.03-110.asw_3: Drive up close to the vehicle in front so you can use its rear lights as an orientation point
1.1.03-110.info:
In difficult visibility conditions, sources of danger are identified later than in normal visibility conditions. It is thus necessary to reduce your speed in order to adapt to the new visibility conditions.

If visibility due to fog, snow or rain is less than 50 m, the speed must not exceed 50 km/h unless a lower speed is required. Your vehicle may only be driven at such a speed that it can be stopped within a clear distance.

The distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you should be adjusted so that your vehicle can stop in time.
1.1.03-110.text: What do you do if visibility is drastically reduced by fog?

1.1.03-114-M.asw_1: Because it is not clear which direction the road will take
1.1.03-114-M.asw_2: Because the road surface is uneven
1.1.03-114-M.asw_3: Because oncoming traffic could cut the corner
1.1.03-114-M.info:
The combination of curve and dense vegetation at the edge of the road makes the course of the road unclear. At the same time, the bend is elongated, which increases the risk of oncoming traffic driving in the middle.

Cobblestones and repaired areas form an uneven road surface, which has different effects on the grip of the tyres.
1.1.03-114-M.text: Why do you have to pay particular attention here?

1.1.04-103-B.asw_1: Look to the right-hand edge of the roadway
1.1.04-103-B.asw_3: Accelerate to get out of the beam of light more quickly
1.1.04-103-B.info: When oncoming traffic is dazzling, do not look directly into the headlights, but turn away your gaze and look as far as possible to the right side of the road. To reduce the risk of a collision due to dazzling traffic, reduce your speed if necessary.
1.1.04-103-B.text: What must you do in this situation when you are dazzled?

1.1.04-107.asw_1: That your vehicle will not be seen in time
1.1.04-107.asw_2: That you only detect oncoming vehicles after it is too late
1.1.04-107.asw_3: That the traffic lights are hardly distinct from the coloured signs
1.1.04-107.info: The colourful neon sign can lead to other motorists seeing your vehicle late. It may be more difficult to detect oncoming vehicles on time. The lights of traffic lights may not be recognized in a timely manner.
1.1.04-107.text: What must you be aware of here?

1.1.05-001.info:
In curves, extreme centrifugal forces can act at high speeds, which can result in a loss of vehicle control.

At intersections and junctions, high speed can result in long braking distances.

There is a risk that crossing pedestrians will be detected too late at pedestrian crossings.
1.1.05-001.text: Where does driving fast often lead to accidents?

1.1.05-002.info:
At road narrowings, too high a speed could lead to a collision with oncoming traffic because the braking distance is too long. At level crossings, there is an increased risk of skidding due to tracks and possibly uneven road surfaces.

In blind corners, driving too fast can result in other motorists being seen too late.
1.1.05-002.text: Where is fast driving particularly dangerous?

1.1.05-003.asw_1: Reduce speed before reaching the bend
1.1.05-003.asw_2: Only accelerate again when the road straightens out
1.1.05-003.asw_3: Reduce speed only when you reach the centre of the bend
1.1.05-003.info:
At tight bends the speed should not be reduced only within the bend, but already beforehand. If you brake hard in a bend, the vehicle could swerve.

The same applies to acceleration in the curve, which is why you should only accelerate at the transition to a straight part of the road.
1.1.05-003.text: How do you take tight bends?

1.1.06-002.asw_1: Yes, because the truck and trailer can obscure the view of important traffic signs
1.1.06-002.asw_2: Yes, because the truck and trailer can obscure the view of the crossing traffic
1.1.06-002.asw_3: No, because trucks and trailers mostly drive at low speed
1.1.06-002.info: Overtaking is not permitted if the traffic situation is unclear. The truck obscures the view of crossing traffic as well as traffic signs.
1.1.06-002.text: Is it irresponsible to overtake a truck and trailer a short distance before a crossroads?

1.1.06-104.asw_pretext: When the road user being overtaken
1.1.06-104.info: Anyone who is being overtaken must not increase the speed of his or her vehicle. This would prolong the overtaking distance of the other vehicle and lead to unnecessary danger. Other hazards, such as pulling out, are also not permitted.
1.1.06-104.text: When are you in danger when overtaking?

1.1.06-105.asw_1: When the road user being overtaken suddenly accelerates
1.1.06-105.asw_2: When there is danger from unexpected oncoming traffic
1.1.06-105.asw_3: When the road user being overtaken considerably reduces his speed
1.1.06-105.info:
If the person caught up with suddenly accelerates, the overtaking procedure must be stopped. The overtaking manoeuvre must also be stopped in the event of sudden oncoming traffic.

Overtaking is only allowed if you can ensure that any oncoming traffic will not be obstructed during the entire time that you are overtaking. Furthermore, overtaking is only allowed if the driver is driving at a significantly higher speed than the person who is to be overtaken.

Anyone who is overtaken must not increase his or her speed.
1.1.06-105.text: In which cases must you abandon overtaking?

1.1.06-106.asw_1: If you are unable to drive considerably faster than the road user being overtaken
1.1.06-106.asw_2: If you do not have a clear view of the road ahead
1.1.06-106.asw_3: If the traffic situation is not clear
1.1.06-106.info:
Overtaking is only allowed if you can ensure that any oncoming traffic will not be obstructed during the entire time that you are overtaking.

Furthermore, overtaking is only allowed if the driver is driving at a significantly higher speed than the person to be overtaken.

Overtaking is not permitted if the traffic situation is unclear.

1.1.07-001.asw_2: - swing out to the left before turning
1.1.07-001.asw_3: - move well over to the right
1.1.07-001.info: Due to the higher centre of gravity and a load that may be present, lorries often have to reduce their speed significantly before entering a curve. Depending on the length, the lorry may need to veer out.
1.1.07-001.text: What must you be prepared for when a truck in front of you wishes to turn right into a narrow street?

1.1.07-002.asw_1: Intersecting roads may have priority even though they are narrow and less well developed
1.1.07-002.asw_2: A better developed road always has priority
1.1.07-002.asw_3: The rule "right before left" applies without exception at all crossroads and junctions
1.1.07-002.info: Priority rules are not determined by the length or width of the road.
1.1.07-002.text: What do you have to particularly remember at crossroads and junctions in a built-up area?

1.1.07-006-B.asw_1: Because there is an increased danger of skidding when braking
1.1.07-006-B.asw_2: Because a vehicle could come from the right
1.1.07-006-B.asw_3: Because the car coming from the left has priority
1.1.07-006-B.info: The leaves cover the roadway, making it difficult to see vehicles on the road coming from the right. A vehicle could approach from the right, and since there are no right-of-way signs, 'right-before-left' applies. Moisture and leaves can impair traction and thus increase braking distance.
1.1.07-006-B.text: Why must you be particularly careful here?

1.1.07-009.asw_1: - rush onto the road without thinking
1.1.07-009.asw_2: - ride their bicycles onto the road without paying attention
1.1.07-009.asw_3: - always conduct themselves properly on the road
1.1.07-009.info: Not all children behave in a roadworthy manner. They could suddenly run into the road. Likewise, they could carelessly enter the road on bicycles.
1.1.07-009.text: You are approaching a school. Children are leaving the school grounds. What must you reckon with?

1.1.07-010.asw_1: To vehicles which have broken down
1.1.07-010.asw_2: To school buses with children boarding or alighting
1.1.07-010.info: Any person operating a regular bus service or a marked school bus must switch on hazard warning lights when approaching a bus stop and while passengers are boarding or alighting, provided that the authority responsible for road transport has ordered such behaviour for certain bus stops in accordance with national law. Apart from stopping and towing vehicles, hazard lights may only be switched on by those who want to endanger others by their vehicle or warn others of dangers, for example when approaching a traffic jam or at particularly slow driving speeds on motorways and other fast-moving roads.
1.1.07-010.text: What do hazard warning lights draw your attention to?

1.1.07-011.asw_1: - will swing far out to the left when turning
1.1.07-011.asw_2: - will slow down drastically before turning
1.1.07-011.asw_3: - cannot swing out due to rear-wheel steering
1.1.07-011.info: Combine harvesters are vehicles with a very high centre of gravity. It is thus necessary for such vehicles to reduce their speed significantly before entering a bend. Due to the dimensions of the vehicle, it may be necessary for the combine harvester to make a wide turn.
1.1.07-011.text: A big combine harvester in front of you wishes to turn right. What is correct?

1.1.07-013.asw_1: Particularly when braking or turning, parts of the load can fall off
1.1.07-013.asw_2: The indicators may be concealed, making it difficult to see when the combination of vehicles wishes to turn off
1.1.07-013.asw_3: The braking distance of the combination of vehicles is particularly short because of its load
1.1.07-013.info: In the case of a laden trailer, it cannot be ruled out that the indicators or other lights may be covered by the load and thus not be visible. Centrifugal forces when turning or braking can cause parts of the load to come loose and fall onto the road from the trailer.
1.1.07-013.text: You are driving behind a farm vehicle with a trailer carrying a high load. What must you reckon with?

1.1.07-015-M.info: The tractor driver's view is restricted. The tractor could drive onto the road at any time. It is thus important to reduce your speed and be ready to brake.
1.1.07-015-M.text: What should you do in this situation?

1.1.07-101.asw_1: The mounted implement can swing out when the tractor turns off
1.1.07-101.asw_2: The rear lights may be heavily soiled or concealed, making direction signals difficult or impossible to see when they are on
1.1.07-101.asw_3: Farm tractors can always be overtaken safely due to their low speed
1.1.07-101.info: With agricultural vehicles there is always a risk of indicators or other lights becoming dirty and thus becoming hard to see. Attachments extend the vehicle and can swivel out accordingly when the vehicle is turning.
1.1.07-101.text: You wish to overtake a farm tractor with a mounted implement extending beyond its back. What must you remember?

1.1.07-103-M.asw_1: A vehicle may be stationary there
1.1.07-103-M.asw_2: There may be an oncoming vehicle on my side of the road
1.1.07-103-M.asw_3: There may be a slow moving vehicle on my side of the road
1.1.07-103-M.info: Visibility is restricted meaning that risks such as oncoming vehicles, slow-moving vehicles or stationary vehicles are only detected at a late stage.
1.1.07-103-M.text: What must you anticipate on the other side of this crest in the road?

1.1.07-107-B.asw_2: Workers and construction equipment on the roadway
1.1.07-107-B.info: Due to the construction site, the road can be uneven and dirty. It cannot be ruled out that construction equipment may be on the carriageway. In addition, construction workers can enter the road at any time.
1.1.07-107-B.text: What must you be prepared for in this situation?

1.1.07-111.asw_1: - make sure there is no road user beside you on the right intending to go straight on
1.1.07-111.asw_2: - simply glance in the mirror to check that there is no cyclist behind you
1.1.07-111.asw_3: - concentrate fully on the turning manoeuvre because any cyclist has to wait anyway
1.1.07-111.info: Even vehicles turning right can cut into the lanes or paths of other motorists. Therefore, it is important to check that there is no one next to the vehicle who wishes to drive straight ahead.
1.1.07-111.text: You are waiting at a traffic light and want to turn right. What should you remember?

1.1.07-113.asw_1: Wild animals unexpectedly crossing the roadway
1.1.07-113.asw_2: An obstruction caused by an accident involving a wild animal
1.1.07-113.asw_3: There is no reason to expect accidents involving wild animals on new roads
1.1.07-113.info: Newly constructed roads in wooded areas pose an increased risk of wildlife crossing the road, as the roadway may run through animal paths. A vehicle in front may already have been involved in an accident, resulting in an obstacle on the road.
1.1.07-113.text: You are driving on a new road through a woodland area. What must you reckon with?

1.1.07-114.asw_1: There could be stragglers following the herd
1.1.07-114.asw_2: The herd may come back and cross the road again
1.1.07-114.asw_3: There is no reason to expect any more animals
1.1.07-114.info: Wild animals such as deer like to travel in groups, so there is a possibility that more animals could follow and cross the road. The behaviour of wild animals is unpredictable; they could turn around and run onto the road again.
1.1.07-114.text: Several deer run across the road in front of your vehicle. What must you reckon with?

1.1.07-117.info: Wild animals can cross the road at any time. Animals are, however, mainly active at dawn as well as at twilight.
1.1.07-117.text: At which time of the day do you have to reckon with increased wild animals crossing?

1.1.07-118.info: In rural areas, road use by agricultural vehicles must be expected. Tractors and other agricultural vehicles are often comparatively slow. The vehicles can be oversized, which requires increased caution, especially when overtaking – if safe overtaking is possible at all. If a vehicle enters the road from a field or forest, the road may become dirty, which in turn can lead to a loss of grip.
1.1.07-118.text: Which dangers must you reckon with above all in rural areas?

1.1.07-119.asw_1: The tractor can carry large work equipment which is difficult to see
1.1.07-119.asw_2: Despite the headlights being switched on, it is not always possible to discern the width of the tractor
1.1.07-119.asw_3: 2 wide trailers can be attached to the tractor
1.1.07-119.info: In the case of agricultural vehicles and their attachments, lights cannot always be mounted at the outermost points. Therefore, the vehicles can be wider than the lighting suggests. Depending on the type of tractor, it may be possible to tow up to two trailers. Depending on the design, the trailer may be wider than the tractor. Attachments can be considerably wider than the tractor, but depending on the type of implement, this is not always immediately obvious – especially in the dark.
1.1.07-119.text: A farm tractor is approaching you at dawn with its headlights switched on. What must you reckon with?

1.1.07-120.asw_1: Drive with dipped headlights also during the day even in well lit tunnels
1.1.07-120.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must use dipped headlights when passing through a tunnel. This also applies if the tunnel is well lit. Sunglasses must be taken off in anticipation of the lack of light inside of the tunnel. Otherwise the perception could be impaired by the sunglasses.
1.1.07-120.text: What must you observe when you enter a tunnel?

1.1.07-121.asw_2: When traffic comes to a standstill, keep a safety distance of approximately 5 m to the car ahead
1.1.07-121.info: When approaching a traffic jam in a tunnel, the hazard warning light warns other approaching vehicles of the increased danger. A sufficient safety distance to the person in front is helpful in order to be able to form an emergency lane quickly and safely if necessary.
1.1.07-121.text: What must you do in case of a traffic jam in a tunnel?

1.1.07-122.asw_1: Reflections of light from oncoming traffic
1.1.07-122.info: While driving in a tunnel, oncoming traffic lighting and reflections are often perceived more intensively, which can impair attention. The longer the tunnel, the more monotonous the ride may appear. This can lead to a faster loss of attention.
1.1.07-122.text: What can impair your attention when driving through a tunnel?

1.1.07-125.asw_1: Drive with dipped headlights also by day even in a well lit tunnel
1.1.07-125.asw_3: Follow instructions and information from the tunnel personnel
1.1.07-125.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must use dipped headlights when passing through a tunnel and must not turn in the tunnel. If tunnel personnel provide concrete information or give instructions, they must be followed.
1.1.07-125.text: Which basic code of conduct must you observe in a tunnel?

1.1.09-004.info: Certain drugs have an effect on sensory perception and can thus reduce the ability to drive. The possible consequences of fatigue are often underestimated and can also affect the ability to drive. Alcohol and other drugs can impair your driving ability.
1.1.09-004.text: What can impair fitness to drive?

1.1.09-006.info: The level of alcohol in the body can be reduced by approx. 0.1 per mille per hour. Thus, the breakdown of 1.0 per mille takes about ten hours.
1.1.09-006.text: In general, how long does it take before an alcohol level of 1.0 per mille (100 mg/100 ml) is cleared from the blood stream?

1.1.09-008.info: Even in small quantities, alcohol can have significant effects. It can impair vision and hearing. It can also affect the ability to react. There is also a risk that it may encourage risky driving.
1.1.09-008.text: What can be the effects of even small quantities of alcohol?

1.1.09-009.asw_3: Prolonged improvement in physical and mental capabilities
1.1.09-009.info: Certain drugs can induce intoxication, which in turn can affect sensory perception. There is also a risk of becoming addicted to certain drugs.

1.1.09-010.info: Even the use of LSD, marijuana, hashish, heroin, cocaine, or amphetamines on a single occasion may cause temporary inability to drive.
1.1.09-010.text: Which drugs can make a person temporarily unfit to drive even when consumed on a single occasion?

1.1.09-015.info: In contrast to alcohol, THC, which is the active ingredient contained in hashish, is not broken down evenly. This means that the time required for breakdown cannot be estimated.
1.1.09-015.text: How is the intoxicating substance in hashish broken down by the body?

1.1.09-017.asw_1: Confiscation of driving licence or driving ban
1.1.09-017.info: Driving under the influence of drugs can be punished in different ways. A driving ban or a withdrawal of the driving licence is a possible consequence. A fine or even imprisonment may be a consequence. The arrangement of a medical-psychological examination (MPU) is possible.
1.1.09-017.text: What are the consequences for a person driving a motor vehicle under the influence of drugs (e.g. hashish, heroin, cocaine)?

1.1.09-018.asw_1: Intoxication with dangerous hallucination and reduced reaction capability
1.1.09-018.info: The possible consequences of consuming hashish are manifold. Among other things, there is a risk of a restriction of sensory perception, including reduced responsiveness. The consumption of hashish may result in intoxication, including confusion, as well as depression occurring at a later point.
1.1.09-018.text: What are the possible effects of hashish consumption?

1.1.09-019.asw_2: Increased likelihood of mistakes in assimilating information
1.1.09-019.info: Driving under the influence of hashish can lead to misinterpretations of speeds and distances. The perception and assessment of hazards is impaired. Errors in the processing of information are also to be expected.
1.1.09-019.text: What are the possible effects of hashish consumption?

1.1.09-021.asw_2: All drivers during their probation period
1.1.09-021.info: It is illegal to drink alcoholic beverages during the probationary period or before the age of 21 as a driver of a motor vehicle on the road or to start driving under the influence of alcohol.
1.1.09-021.text: Who is not allowed to drink alcohol when driving motor vehicles?

1.1.09-022.asw_2: Yes, up to a blood alcohol level of 50 milligrams if they have not committed any alcohol related traffic violation
1.1.09-022.asw_3: Yes, up to a blood alcohol level of 30 milligrams if they have not committed any alcohol related traffic violation
1.1.09-022.info: It is illegal to drink alcoholic beverages during the probationary period according to § 2a or before the age of 21 as a driver of a motor vehicle in road traffic or to start driving under the influence of alcohol
1.1.09-022.text: Are drivers during their probation period allowed to be under the influence of alcohol when driving motor vehicles?

1.2.01-001.asw_1: - reckon with improper conduct on the part of others
1.2.01-001.asw_3: - insist on your right of priority at all times
1.2.01-001.info: Participation in road traffic requires constant caution and mutual respect. Anyone taking part in traffic must behave in such a way that no one else is harmed, endangered or harassed.
1.2.01-001.text: Participation in road traffic requires caution at all times and consideration towards other road users. What does this mean for you?

1.2.02-101-B.info:
Anyone driving a vehicle may not cross the undivided line partially. If it delimits a paved side strip, agricultural tractors and machinery, carts and similar slow vehicles outside of built-up areas must drive as far to the right of it as possible.

Any person driving a vehicle should not stop on the left of the undivided line if there is a hard shoulder or special lane on the right.
1.2.02-101-B.text: When may you use the right-hand hard shoulder?

1.2.03-001.asw_1: Towing a trailer not fitted with brakes
1.2.03-001.info: Moisture and slipperiness result in reduced traction and thus increase braking distance. On a slope, the car accelerates due to the downforce of the slope, which extends the braking distance. A trailer increases the mass of the vehicle, which results in a longer braking distance with the same braking force.
1.2.03-001.text: Which factors lengthen your braking distance?

1.2.03-002.info: The condition of a braking system influences the braking distance. New brakes with good discs and full brake pads work best. The road surface has a large influence. For example, slipperiness can significantly increase braking distance. The type of tyres and tread depth influence the braking distance.
1.2.03-002.text: What does the braking distance depend on?

1.2.03-101.info: Unless there are other restrictions, a maximum speed of 50 km/h applies to all motor vehicles in built-up areas.
1.2.03-101.text: What is the permissible top speed generally in built-up areas?

1.2.03-102.info: A doubling of the speed results in a quadrupling of the braking distance. The rule of thumb for braking distance is as follows: (speed / 10) x (speed / 10).
1.2.03-102.text: You double the speed at which you are travelling. How does this affect the braking distance?

1.2.03-103.asw_2: The condition of the road and traffic conditions
1.2.03-103.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may only drive as fast as allows the vehicle to be constantly controlled. The speed should be adapted to road, traffic, visibility and weather conditions as well as to personal ability and characteristics of the vehicle and load.
1.2.03-103.text: What must you take into consideration when selecting your speed?

1.2.03-104.info:
The average reaction time of a human being is 1 second. The distance covered by a vehicle in one second is therefore the "reaction distance".

The rule of thumb for the calculation is as follows:

Reaction distance = (speed / 10) x 3.
1.2.03-104.text: By which rule of thumb can you determine from the speed the distance in metres a motor vehicle travels in one second?

1.2.03-105.info: The rule of thumb for braking distance is as follows: (speed in km/h / 10) x (speed in km/h / 10).
1.2.03-105.text: By which rule of thumb can you determine the braking distance in metres from speed when braking normally?

1.2.03-106.info: The braking distance is increased by the driving speed squared. Therefore, a doubling of the speed results in a quadrupling of the braking distance. The rule of thumb for stopping distance is as follows: (speed in km/h / 10) x (speed in km/h / 10) Stopping distance = (60/10) x (60/10) = 36 m.
1.2.03-106.text: You are travelling at 30 km/h. According to the rule of thumb, the braking distance is 9 metres when braking normally. How long is the braking distance under the same conditions when travelling at 60 km/h?

1.2.04-101.info: As a rule, the distance to a vehicle in front must be such that it can be retained even if the vehicle in front brakes suddenly. Poor visibility, high speed and poor (e.g., wet) road conditions have a direct influence on reaction distance, stopping distance and braking distance.
1.2.04-101.text: What does the distance to be maintained from the vehicle ahead depend on?

1.2.05-101.asw_1: When the traffic situation is not clear
1.2.05-101.asw_2: Where oncoming traffic could be obstructed
1.2.05-101.info: Overtaking is only allowed if you can ensure that the possibility of any obstruction of oncoming traffic is excluded during the entire overtaking process. Overtaking is not permitted if the traffic situation is unclear.

1.2.05-103.asw_1: Any danger to traffic following is excluded
1.2.05-103.asw_3: The vehicle in front indicates right
1.2.05-103.info: Anyone who wants to overtake has to behave in such a way that there is no danger to the traffic behind his or her vehicle. When overtaking, sufficient lateral clearance must be maintained from other motorists, in particular from pedestrians and cyclists. If you overtake, you have to get back into the right lane as soon as possible. Those who overtake must not hinder those who are being overtaken.
1.2.05-103.text: What is the correct procedure for pulling out to overtake?

1.2.05-104.asw_1: Move over to the right as soon as possible without inconveniencing the vehicle you have overtaken
1.2.05-104.asw_2: Signal your intention to draw in clearly and in good time
1.2.05-104.asw_3: Move over to the right-hand side of the roadway right in front of the vehicle you have overtaken
1.2.05-104.info: If you overtake, you have to get back into the right lane as soon as possible. Those who overtake must not hinder those who are being overtaken. The overtaking and repositioning of the vehicle shall be signalled clearly and in a timely manner, using your indicators.
1.2.05-104.text: What must you do to end an overtaking manoeuvre?

1.2.05-105.asw_1: The speed of the overtaking vehicle must be appreciably higher
1.2.05-105.asw_2: The permissible top speed must not be exceeded
1.2.05-105.asw_3: The person being overtaken must not increase his speed
1.2.05-105.info: Anyone who is being overtaken must not increase his or her speed. It is necessary to continue driving at a constant speed or to decelerate if necessary. The overtaking driver must drive at a much higher speed to complete the overtaking manoeuvre quickly. However, the overtaking driver must be under control of the vehicle at all times. Exceeding the maximum speed is also not permitted during overtaking.
1.2.05-105.text: What are the regulations governing speed when overtaking?

1.2.05-106.asw_1: If possible, drive on the far right
1.2.05-106.info: Anyone who is being overtaken must not increase his or her speed. It is important to drive as far to the right as possible.
1.2.05-106.text: What must you do when you are being overtaken?

1.2.05-107.asw_3: On the left only if other vehicles are blocking the roadway on the right
1.2.05-107.info: Overtaking from the right is not allowed in most situations. But rail vehicles have to be overtaken on the right. Only those who cannot do this because the rails are too far to the right are allowed to overtake on the left. Railway vehicles may also be overtaken on the left on one-way streets.
1.2.05-107.text: On which side must you overtake a tram which is travelling in the middle of the roadway (not a one-way street)?

1.2.05-108.asw_2: When the rails run too far to the right
1.2.05-108.asw_3: When the roadway (not a one-way street) to the right of the tram is blocked by other vehicles
1.2.05-108.info: Rail vehicles must be overtaken on the right. Only those who cannot do this because the rails are too far to the right are allowed to overtake on the left. Railway vehicles may also be overtaken on the left on one-way streets.
1.2.05-108.text: When may a tram be overtaken on the left?

1.2.05-109.info: Anyone who wants to overtake has to behave in such a way that there is no danger to the traffic behind his or her vehicle. When overtaking, sufficient lateral clearance must be maintained from other motorists, in particular from pedestrians and cyclists (not only bicycles but also motorcycles).
1.2.05-109.text: Which vehicles may be overtaken only by maintaining a specially great lateral distance?

1.2.05-110.asw_1: Before pulling out to overtake or to pass
1.2.05-110.asw_2: Before pulling in again after overtaking
1.2.05-110.asw_3: When proceeding straight ahead as you leave a priority road which bends sharply
1.2.05-110.info: The overtaking and repositioning of the vehicle should be signalled clearly and in a timely manner by using your indicators.

1.2.06-001.asw_1: The vehicle on the side of the roadway where the roadworks are
1.2.06-001.asw_2: The vehicle on the unobstructed side of the roadway
1.2.06-001.info: If you want to drive past a narrowing of the roadway, an obstacle on the roadway or a stopping vehicle on the left, you must allow oncoming vehicles to pass. This does not apply if indicated otherwise by traffic signs.
1.2.06-001.text: Which vehicle must wait when half the roadway is closed because of roadworks?

1.2.07-001.asw_1: You must signal your intention to change lanes in time
1.2.07-001.asw_2: You must pay attention to the traffic following behind
1.2.07-001.asw_3: You must always brake heavily before changing lanes
1.2.07-001.info: A lane may only be changed if there is no danger to other motorists. Any change of lane should be signalled clearly and in a timely manner and indicators should be used. Attention must be paid to the traffic behind you.
1.2.07-001.text: What must you remember when you want to change lanes?

1.2.07-103.asw_1: Only move over just before the road starts to narrow by following the zipper feed-in method
1.2.07-103.asw_2: Move into the through lane immediately after you see the first sign indicating that the road will narrow
1.2.07-103.asw_3: Always be the first to move over into the through lane
1.2.07-103.info: On roads with several lanes for one direction, if it is not possible to drive continuously on one lane or if one lane ends, the vehicles prevented from continuing should be allowed to pass over to the adjacent lane in such a way that these vehicles can alternate with a vehicle travelling on the continuous lane immediately before the narrowing begins (zipper feed-in method).
1.2.07-103.text: On a road with several lanes in one direction, one of the lanes ends ahead. You are driving on the lane which is coming to an end. What should you do?

1.2.07-104.asw_1: Do not drive over the lane boundary markings
1.2.07-104.asw_3: Drive over the lane boundary markings when overtaking
1.2.07-104.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must use dipped headlights when passing through a tunnel and must not turn in the tunnel. The undivided line may not even be partially crossed.
1.2.07-104.text: What do you do in a tunnel with oncoming traffic?

1.2.09-101.asw_2: Changing lanes while performing the turn
1.2.09-101.info: Changing lanes while turning off involves risks, such as collisions with vehicles that have been overlooked. If you drive too fast, you risk losing your grip and thus losing control of your vehicle.
1.2.09-101.text: What can give rise to particularly dangerous situations where several lanes turn off?

1.2.09-103-B.info: Only the yellow car is in the correct lane. The green car is too far to the left; it should have passed the traffic island on the right. The truck, on the other hand, is too far to the right.
1.2.09-103-B.text: All three vehicles want to turn left. Which is in the correct lane?

1.2.09-104-B.info: After turning left, leave the lane to the right at the next junction. Consequently, it makes sense to position your vehicle in the right lane like the red car so that you will not have to change lanes later.
1.2.09-104-B.text: After turning left, you want to turn immediately right. How should you position your vehicle?

1.2.09-107-B.info: The motorcyclist is following the priority road which is why he has to indicate.
1.2.09-107-B.text: Who must signal a change of direction here?

1.2.09-109.asw_1: You can only drive over a central island if this is unavoidable because of your vehicle's size
1.2.09-109.asw_2: You are not allowed to stop on the roadway in a roundabout
1.2.09-109.asw_3: You must indicate to leave the roundabout
1.2.09-109.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may not drive over the central island of the roundabout. This prohibition does not apply to vehicles whose dimensions would otherwise prevent them from being driven on these roads. Vehicles must not stop on the road within the roundabout. If you want to turn, you must signal this clearly and in a timely manner, using your indicators.
1.2.09-109.text: You are on a roundabout. What should you remember?

1.2.09-113-M.info: All motorists involved want to turn and must indicate.
1.2.09-113-M.text: Who is required to indicate a change of driving direction here?

1.2.09-117.asw_1: Before turning into a junction or a property lot
1.2.09-117.asw_2: If I want to continue following a priority road that changes direction
1.2.09-117.asw_3: If I want to continue straight on, thereby leaving a priority road that changes direction
1.2.09-117.info: If you want to turn, you must announce this clearly and in a timely manner by using your indicators. Turning into junctions or plots of land must be indicated. If a priority road bends, motorists that want to follow the priority road must also signal to indicate their intent.
1.2.09-117.text: When do have you to indicate a change in direction?

1.2.10-005.asw_1: Whoever turns into a road over a sunken kerbstone must wait
1.2.10-005.asw_3: The sunken kerbstone is of no relevance for the obligation to wait
1.2.10-005.info: Whoever wants to drive over a lowered kerbstone onto the road or from the edge of the road has to wait and behave in such a way that there is no danger to other motorists.
1.2.10-005.text: You want to turn out of a road with a sunken kerbstone into another road. A car is coming from the left. What applies here?

1.2.10-101.asw_3: A look into the rear-view mirror is sufficient
1.2.10-101.info: If you want to start driving from the edge of the road, you must behave in such a way that there is no danger to other motorists. If necessary, let yourself be directed. The intention to enter the road or start the vehicle must be signalled clearly and in a timely manner by using the direction indicators.
1.2.10-101.text: What must you do when leaving the edge of the roadway?

1.2.11-003.info: If there is traffic congestion, you must not drive into the crossroads or junction despite the right of way or green light signal. If the level crossing cannot be crossed quickly and without a stop due to road traffic, wait in front of the diagonal cross.
1.2.11-003.text: Which are the areas you must not drive into when there is traffic congestion?

1.2.11-005-B.asw_1: Reduce speed and, if necessary, stop
1.2.11-005-B.asw_2: Proceed, pulling over onto the pavement
1.2.11-005-B.asw_3: Speed up and proceed since the oncoming traffic must wait
1.2.11-005-B.info: Priority should be given to oncoming traffic. You must reduce your speed and, if necessary, you must wait so that oncoming traffic can pass.

1.2.12-001.asw_2: On narrow sections of the road and at blind spots
1.2.12-001.info: It is not permitted to stop in narrow and unclear places on the road or at level crossings.

1.2.12-002.asw_1: At the edge of the roadway if this would prevent others from using designated parking areas
1.2.12-002.asw_2: On priority roads outside built-up areas
1.2.12-002.asw_3: On priority roads within built-up areas
1.2.12-002.info: Parking is not permitted if it prevents the use of marked parking spaces. Anyone driving a vehicle is not permitted to park on the lanes of priority roads outside built-up areas .

1.2.12-103.asw_1: On the roadway, if there is a sufficiently wide hard shoulder on the right
1.2.12-103.asw_2: Between lane dividers when direction arrows are marked on the roadway
1.2.12-103.info: Anyone driving a vehicle is not allowed to stop on the track marked with arrows. Anyone driving a vehicle may not park on the road if there is not a lane of at least 3 m between the parked vehicle and the lane boundary line. Anyone driving a vehicle is not permitted to stop at taxi ranks, except for taxis dropping off or picking up passengers.

1.2.12-104.asw_1: On pedestrian crossings and up to 5 m before pedestrian crossings
1.2.12-104.asw_3: Over manholes and other road covers
1.2.12-104.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must not stop on pedestrian crossings or up to 5 m before the pedestrian crossing.

1.2.12-105.asw_1: At the edge of the roadway if this would prevent others from using designated parking areas
1.2.12-105.info: Parking is not permitted if it prevents the use of marked parking spaces. Parking in front of kerbs is also prohibited.

1.2.12-106.asw_2: Where there are rails on the right-hand side
1.2.12-106.asw_3: Where parking is prohibited on the right
1.2.12-106.info: If there are rails on the right side or you are in a one-way street, parking on the left side of the road is allowed.
1.2.12-106.text: Where are you allowed to park on the left in the direction of travel?

1.2.12-107.asw_1: Anyone who stops for more than 3 minutes
1.2.12-107.asw_3: Anyone who waits longer than 3 minutes at a closed level crossing barrier
1.2.12-107.info: Anyone who leaves their vehicle or has stopped for more than three minutes has parked.

1.2.12-108.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must not stop on pedestrian crossings or up to 5 m in front of them.
1.2.12-108.text: What is the minimum distance you must leave clear when stopping or parking in front of a pedestrian crossing?

1.2.12-110.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may not park up to 5 m in front of or behind the St. Andrew's Cross in built-up areas and up to 50 m outside of built-up areas.
1.2.12-110.text: What is the minimum distance you must leave clear when parking outside a built-up area before a St. Andrew's Cross?

1.2.12-111.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may not park up to 5 m in front of or behind the St. Andrew's Cross in built-up areas and up to 50 m outside of built-up areas.
1.2.12-111.text: You want to park in front of a St. Andrew's Cross in a built-up area. What is the minimum distance you must leave clear?

1.2.12-112.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may not park up to 15 m in front of or behind a stop sign.
1.2.12-112.text: Up to what distance is it prohibited to park before or after a bus or tram stop sign?

1.2.12-113.info: Parking is forbidden at bus stops. Anyone who remains there for longer than three minutes is considered to have parked.
1.2.12-113.text: What is the maximum length of time you are allowed to stop at a bus stop provided you do not present an obstruction to buses?

1.2.12-123-M.asw_1: It is not permitted to stop to the left of the boundary line of the carriageway
1.2.12-123-M.asw_2: Slower moving vehicles must use the hard shoulder if possible
1.2.12-123-M.asw_3: Driving across the boundary line of the carriageway is prohibited at all times
1.2.12-123-M.info: Stopping is not permitted on the left side of the lane boundary. The side strip is to be used by slow vehicles, such as tractors.
1.2.12-123-M.text: What must you be aware of here?

1.2.16-101.info: The horn is an audible signal. Sound and light signals may only be given by those who overtake outside built-up areas or who see themselves or others endangered.
1.2.16-101.text: For which purposes is a horn allowed to be used outside built-up areas?

1.2.16-102.info: The horn is an audible signal. Sound and light signals may only be given by those who overtake outside built-up areas or who see themselves or others endangered. In urban areas, however, the horn may only serve as a warning signal.
1.2.16-102.text: For which purposes is a horn allowed to be used in built-up areas?

1.2.16-103.asw_1: Switch on the hazard warning lights
1.2.16-103.asw_2: If possible, park the vehicle in an emergency bay
1.2.16-103.asw_3: Let the engine run by way of precaution
1.2.16-103.info: In order not to endanger other motorists or yourself, you should drive on to the next emergency bay, if possible. In the tunnel exhaust fumes do not dissipate as easily, which is why the engine must be switched off to prevent poisoning. If a multi-lane vehicle stops at a point where it cannot be detected in time as a stationary obstacle, hazard lights must be switched on immediately.
1.2.16-103.text: What do you do in case of a breakdown in a tunnel?

1.2.16-104.asw_1: Switch on the hazard warning lights
1.2.16-104.asw_2: Make a U-turn and leave the tunnel
1.2.16-104.asw_3: At the end of the traffic jam, switch off the engine and leave the vehicle
1.2.16-104.info: When approaching a traffic jam, the hazard warning light serves as a signal to warn following vehicles. Turning is forbidden in the tunnel, and the vehicle may not be left.
1.2.16-104.text: You are driving in a tunnel and approach the end of a traffic jam. What do you do?

1.2.17-001.asw_3: It must be in operating condition
1.2.17-001.info: Lighting devices should be fixed to vehicles or load carriers according to the number and type of lighting devices prescribed. The lighting equipment must not be obscured or dirty.
1.2.17-001.text: What must you remember concerning the lighting equipment of your vehicle?

1.2.19-002.asw_1: When a flashing red light comes on
1.2.19-002.asw_2: When the barriers are being lowered
1.2.19-002.asw_3: When a railway employee is waving a white-red-white flag
1.2.19-002.info: Vehicles must wait for pedestrians at a safe distance in front of the level crossing when a red flashing light or yellow or red light signals are given, when a railway employee orders motorists to stop, or when the barriers are lowered or closed.
1.2.19-002.text: When must you wait at a level crossing?

1.2.19-003.asw_1: Wait in front of the St. Andrew's Cross
1.2.19-003.asw_2: Proceed as long as the half barrier is open
1.2.19-003.asw_3: If no rail vehicle is in sight, cross the level crossing
1.2.19-003.info: Vehicles must wait in front of the St. Andrew's Cross when red flashing lights or yellow or red light signals are given or when the barriers are lowered or closed.
1.2.19-003.text: You are approaching a level crossing with half barriers and flashing lights. The red light is flashing but the barrier is still open. What do you do?

1.2.19-004.asw_1: You must wait in front of the level crossing
1.2.19-004.asw_2: You may cross the rails carefully
1.2.19-004.asw_3: The red lamp is of no significance for you
1.2.19-004.info: Vehicles must wait for pedestrians at a safe distance in front of the level crossing if a railway employee orders motorists to stop.
1.2.19-004.text: A railway employee is waving a red lamp at a level crossing. What does this mean?

1.2.19-005.asw_1: Approach at moderate speed, look along the railway line
1.2.19-005.asw_2: Wait in front of the level crossing if you would have to wait on it because of traffic congestion
1.2.19-005.asw_3: Proceed at the same speed as road traffic always has precedence in such cases
1.2.19-005.info: Road traffic may approach such level crossings only at a moderate speed. If the level crossing cannot be crossed quickly and without a stop due to road traffic, wait in front of the level crossing.
1.2.19-005.text: You are approaching a level crossing where the barriers are open. What do you do?

1.2.19-008.asw_1: Approach level crossings at moderate speed only
1.2.19-008.asw_2: Rail vehicles have precedence at all level crossings
1.2.19-008.asw_3: Motor vehicles have precedence at level crossings without St. Andrew's Cross
1.2.19-008.info: The St. Andrew's Cross calls for increased attention, in particular a reduction of speed in view of a dangerous situation. Rail vehicles have priority on level crossings with a St. Andrew's Cross as well as in port and industrial areas, if the St. Andrew's Cross with the additional sign "Port area, rail vehicles have priority" or "Industrial area, rail vehicles have priority" is shown at the entrances.
1.2.19-008.text: At the entrance to an industrial estate, there is a St. Andrew's Cross with the supplementary sign "Industrial estate, rail vehicles have precedence". What must you remember?

1.2.19-101.asw_1: Proceed at moderate speed and check to see if a rail vehicle is approaching
1.2.19-101.asw_2: Listen out in case a rail vehicle signals its approach by whistling or ringing a bell
1.2.19-101.asw_3: Proceed without taking any special precautions since rail vehicles are required to wait here
1.2.19-101.info: Railway vehicles have priority on level crossings over footpaths, field paths, forest paths or cycle paths. Road traffic may approach such level crossings only at a moderate speed. Approaching rail vehicles can be announced by a ringing or whistling signal.
1.2.19-101.text: You are driving along a forest track and approach a level crossing without St. Andrew's Cross. What do you do?

1.2.19-102.asw_1: Wait before the St. Andrew's Cross without obstructing junctions
1.2.19-102.asw_2: If possible, switch on the side lights when it is dark
1.2.19-102.asw_3: Use the road area and wait directly in front of the barrier
1.2.19-102.info: Vehicles must wait in front of the St. Andrew's Cross when the barriers are lowered or closed. The headlamps of waiting motor vehicles must not dazzle anybody.
1.2.19-102.text: What do you do at a level crossing when the barriers are closed?

1.2.19-104.asw_1: When the flashing red light goes out
1.2.19-104.asw_2: Immediately after the train has passed, even if the flashing red light is still on
1.2.19-104.asw_3: As soon as the oncoming traffic sets off, even if the flashing red light is still on
1.2.19-104.info: Vehicles must wait in front of the level crossing when a red flashing light or yellow or red light signals are given – even if the train has already passed through the crossing.
1.2.19-104.text: When are you allowed to cross a level crossing with flashing lights but no barriers after a train has passed?

1.2.19-105.asw_1: In front of the St. Andrew's Cross
1.2.19-105.info: If the level crossing cannot be crossed quickly and without a stop due to road traffic, wait in front of the St. Andrew's Cross.
1.2.19-105.text: You are approaching a level crossing with barriers. Where must you wait if you would have to stop on the rails in case of traffic congestion?

1.2.19-107.asw_1: In front of the St. Andrew's Cross
1.2.19-107.info: Vehicles must wait in front of the level crossing when the barriers are lowered or closed.
1.2.19-107.text: The barrier of a level crossing inside a built-up area is closed. Where must you wait?

1.2.19-109.asw_1: Indication of existing overhead electrical wires
1.2.19-109.asw_3: You must always wait when a rail vehicle is approaching
1.2.19-109.info: The St. Andrew's Cross (also appearing horizontally) is usually located directly in front of the level crossing. An illuminated arrow in the middle of the St. Andrew's Cross indicates that the railway line has a live overhead electrical line. Rail vehicles have priority on level crossings with St. Andrew's Cross.
1.2.19-109.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

1.2.19-110.asw_2: In front of the light signal, if there is no stop line
1.2.19-110.asw_3: I can drive up to the level crossing after watching out for other traffic
1.2.19-110.info: Red orders: "Stop at the intersection". You have to wait at the stop line. If there is no line, wait at the light signal.
1.2.19-110.text: A light signal with no level crossing sign is positioned before a level crossing, and in front of a junction with a road to the right. The red light is illuminated. Where must you wait?

1.2.20-003.asw_1: Drive past at walking speed only and, if necessary, stop
1.2.20-003.asw_2: Drive past at a sufficient distance in order to exclude endangering pedestrians
1.2.20-003.asw_3: Wait if passengers could be inconvenienced
1.2.20-003.info: Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even in the event of oncoming traffic. When passengers are boarding or disembarking, vehicles may only pass on the right side at a walking speed and only at such a distance that there is no danger to passengers. They must also not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.2.20-003.text: What do you do when a bus has stopped at a bus stop with its hazard warning lights switched on?

1.2.20-004.info: Buses and coaches used for regular and school transport should be able to depart from marked bus stops. If necessary, other vehicles must wait.
1.2.20-004.text: Which vehicles must you allow to set off from marked bus stops?

1.2.20-005.asw_2: Only proceed at walking speed if passengers want to cross the roadway
1.2.20-005.asw_3: Proceed at the same speed since the bus has stopped on the other side of the roadway
1.2.20-005.info: Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even in the event of oncoming traffic. When passengers are boarding or disembarking, vehicles may only pass on the right side at a walking speed and only at such a distance that there is no danger to passengers. They must also not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.2.20-005.text: A regular bus in the oncoming traffic has stopped at a bus stop on the same roadway with hazard warning lights switched on. What do you do?

1.2.20-101.asw_1: Passengers will cross the roadway in order to catch the bus
1.2.20-101.asw_2: Passengers leaving the bus will suddenly cross the roadway
1.2.20-101.asw_3: Passengers will cross the roadway only after the hazard warning lights of the bus are switched off
1.2.20-101.info: You must expect pedestrians wanting to reach the bus in a hurry. Likewise, disembarking passengers could run directly across the carriageway.
1.2.20-101.text: You are approaching a regular bus which has stopped in the opposite direction at a bus stop on your roadway and its hazard warning lights are switched on. What must you expect?

1.2.22-101.info: The load may extend beyond the reflectors by up to 1 m without any marking being necessary.
1.2.22-101.text: What is the maximum distance a load may project backwards beyond the rear reflectors without a projection marker being necessary?

1.2.22-102.asw_1: By a red light and red rear reflector
1.2.22-102.asw_3: By switching the fog tail lamp on
1.2.22-102.info: A load extending more than 1 m beyond the reflectors must be marked. In darkness, at least one lamp with a red light shall be placed in the same place, and a red retro-reflector which shall not be placed higher than 90 cm.
1.2.22-102.text: How must a load projecting more than 1 m beyond the rear reflectors of the vehicle be marked in darkness?

1.2.22-104.asw_3: There may be too much strain on the load-bearing parts of the vehicle
1.2.22-104.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must also ensure that the vehicle, the load, the rig and the occupants are in accordance with the regulations and that the road safety of the vehicle is not adversely affected by the load or occupants. Overloading can have a significant influence on the vehicle and driving behaviour. There is a risk of overloading the brake system. The steering behaviour can deteriorate. There is also a risk of damage to load-bearing vehicle parts.
1.2.22-104.text: What can be the effect of an overload of only 20%?

1.2.22-106.info: Dangerous goods transporters must be labelled with orange warning signs.
1.2.22-106.text: What is the significance of orange warning plates on a vehicle?

1.2.23-001.info: Anyone driving a vehicle remove the vehicle, the train or the combination from service by the shortest possible route if any defects occur during the journey that significantly impair road safety are not rectified immediately. In addition to the driver, the owner is also responsible for the roadworthiness of the vehicle.
1.2.23-001.text: Who is responsible for the roadworthiness of a licensed vehicle?

1.2.23-002.asw_1: Take the vehicle out of the traffic as quickly as possible
1.2.23-002.asw_2: Continue only when the damage has been repaired
1.2.23-002.asw_3: Proceed to the next authorised dealer
1.2.23-002.info: Anyone driving a vehicle remove the vehicle, the train or the combination from service by the shortest possible route if any defects occur during the journey that significantly impair road safety are not rectified immediately. The continuation of the journey is only permitted after the damage has been repaired.
1.2.23-002.text: What must you do when you are travelling and you notice that your vehicle is no longer roadworthy?

1.2.23-003.info: Worn tyres reduce road grip and can thus endanger other motorists. Defective tail lights also pose a danger. The same applies to insufficient braking, for example, due to worn brake linings.
1.2.23-003.text: Which defects of a vehicle can result in a danger for road traffic?

1.2.26-005.info: There is a no-parking zone on the zebra crossing. Parking is thus not permitted. In addition, overtaking must not occur.
1.2.26-005.text: What applies immediately before and on zebra crossings?

1.2.34-103.asw_1: Make the scene of the accident safe
1.2.34-103.asw_2: Drive to the next telephone box and call the rescue service
1.2.34-103.asw_3: Check the seriousness of the injuries
1.2.34-103.info: The first step is to secure the accident site in order to warn other motorists and protect those involved.
1.2.34-103.text: You are the first person to arrive at the scene of an accident with injured persons. What should you do first as a rule?

1.2.34-106.info: In the event of an accident or breakdown on the motorway, help can be requested by calling the telephone numbers 110 and 112. If no mobile phone or mobile network is available, the nearest emergency call point or motorway service area can be used for this purpose.
1.2.34-106.text: How can you get help on an autobahn?

1.2.34-109.asw_1: Switch on the hazard warning lights
1.2.34-109.asw_2: Inform emergency services via the SOS-telephone
1.2.34-109.info: If a multi-lane vehicle stops at a point where it cannot be detected in time as a stationary obstacle, hazard lights must be switched on immediately. This serves to warn the motorists following the stopped vehicle in a timely manner. After the vehicle has been parked safely, the accident site must be properly secured. Subsequently, victims are to be helped and/or an emergency service is to be informed.
1.2.34-109.text: You notice an accident in the tunnel. What do you have to do?

1.2.36-001.info: The signs and instructions of the police officers are to be followed. They take precedence over all other orders and other rules, but do not release the motorist from the duty to pay attention.
1.2.36-001.text: A police officer is regulating the traffic at a crossroads even though the traffic lights are in operation. What applies?

1.2.36-003.asw_2: They must be obeyed only if they tally with the traffic signs installed
1.2.36-003.asw_3: They release you from your own duty to take care
1.2.36-003.info: The signs and instructions of the police officers are to be followed. They take precedence over all other orders and other rules, but do not release the motorist from the duty to pay attention.
1.2.36-003.text: How important are instructions from police officers?

1.2.36-004-B.asw_1: The yellow car must leave the crossroads
1.2.36-004-B.asw_2: I must get ready to proceed
1.2.36-004-B.info: The gesture of the raising of an arm performed by a police officer regulating traffic indicates "wait for the next sign before crossing". Motorists at the intersection must clear the intersection.

1.2.36-005-B.info: The gesture of one or both arms outstretched sideways across the direction of travel performed by a police officer controlling the traffic indicates: "Stop at the intersection".

1.2.36-007.asw_3: To all vehicles on the road
1.2.36-007.info: Police officers may stop motorists for traffic checks, including roadworthiness checks, and for road surveys. A police officer may also give a sign to stop by means of appropriate technical equipment on the emergency vehicle, an indicator signalling disc or a red light. These signs can also be used to stop a preceding road user. Motorists must follow the instructions of the police officers. Depending on its use, the symbol may apply to the vehicle immediately behind or in front of it.
1.2.36-007.text: In your rear-view mirror, you see the words "STOP POLIZEI" (Stop Police) in red illuminated letters on the roof of a police car immediately behind your car. Who does this apply to?

1.2.36-008.asw_1: Only you must follow the police car
1.2.36-008.asw_2: All cars driving in the same direction must follow the police car
1.2.36-008.asw_3: Only heavy goods transports must follow the police car
1.2.36-008.info: Police officers may stop motorists for traffic checks, including roadworthiness checks, and for road surveys. A police officer may also give a sign to stop by means of appropriate technical equipment on the emergency vehicle, an indicator signalling disc or a red light. These signs can also be used to stop a preceding road user. Motorists must follow the instructions of the police officers. Depending on its use, the symbol may apply to the vehicle immediately behind or in front of it.
1.2.36-008.text: The words "BITTE FOLGEN" (PLEASE FOLLOW) are illuminated on a police car immediately preceding your car. What does this mean?

1.2.36-101-B.asw_2: You must wait for further signals from the police officer before the crossroads may be entered
1.2.36-101-B.info: Sideways extension of one arm or both arms across the direction of travel by a police officer directing traffic means: "Stop before the intersection". This applies here to cross traffic.I may cross the intersection.

1.2.37-002-B.asw_2: I may turn observing the traffic signs
1.2.37-002-B.asw_3: I may only turn when the lights show "green"
1.2.37-002-B.info: Due to the red traffic light, the green car has to wait. Turning to the right is permitted, whereby the traffic sign must be observed, i.e., right-of-way cross traffic must be allowed through.

1.2.37-007.asw_1: Turn right from the right lane after having stopped first, when there is no obstruction or danger to others
1.2.37-007.asw_3: Turn right only when the traffic lights are green
1.2.37-007.info: A single-field signal transmitter with a green arrow indicates that when the red light applies to the straight-ahead direction, it is permissible to turn to the right. Nevertheless, it is important to stop and consider that lateral traffic, cyclists and pedestrians have priority.
1.2.37-007.text: What is permitted at these traffic lights with green arrow sign?

1.2.37-009.asw_2: Before the crossing or junction if there is no stop line
1.2.37-009.asw_3: There is no need to stop
1.2.37-009.info: A single-field signal transmitter with a green arrow indicates that when the red light applies to the straight-ahead direction, it is permissible to turn to the right. Nevertheless, it is important to keep to the stop line. If there is no stop line, stop at the intersection or junction.
1.2.37-009.text: At these traffic lights with a green arrow sign, where should a vehicle stop before turning right?

1.2.37-010-M.asw_1: Pass through the crossing without stopping
1.2.37-010-M.asw_2: Stop on the line of sight
1.2.37-010-M.info: The traffic light takes precedence over other traffic signs that regulate priority. Therefore, the crossing must be crossed without stopping.
1.2.37-010-M.text: How should you behave in this situation?

1.2.37-101.asw_3: You must come to an agreement since there are no rules for this
1.2.37-101.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction.
1.2.37-101.text: You want to turn left and the lights are "green". On your left there is a tram wanting to proceed straight ahead. What is correct?

1.2.37-102-B.asw_3: To the left when the traffic lights are "green"
1.2.37-102-B.info: Due to the solid line, changing lanes is not permitted. The arrows specify the direction in which you may continue. Therefore, you may only drive either straight ahead or turn right.
1.2.37-102-B.text: You have taken the right lane by mistake although you want to turn left. How are you allowed to proceed?

1.2.38-002.asw_1: Where is the emergency vehicle coming from?
1.2.38-002.asw_2: Could I obstruct the emergency vehicle?
1.2.38-002.asw_3: Is this vehicle allowed to use a siren at all?
