2.6.03-105.asw_2: The breakaway cable is connected to the towing vehicle
2.6.03-105.asw_3: The permissible maximum speed for this combination of vehicles is 60 km/h, including on autobahns
2.6.03-105.info: A trailer may only be carried if the permissible trailer load is not exceeded. It is necessary to establish a connection between the car and the trailer using the breakaway cable.
2.6.03-105.text: What must you remember when you want to use a trailer with overrun brakes behind your car?

2.6.03-106.asw_2: The permissible total mass of the trailer
2.6.03-106.asw_3: The useful load of the trailer
2.6.03-106.info: The towed load is the load that is actually pulled.
2.6.03-106.text: What is designated as towed load?

2.7.01-043.asw_1: As a rule, the effect of disc brakes starts later than on a dry road surface
2.7.01-043.asw_2: As a rule, the effect of disc brakes starts earlier than on a dry road surface
2.7.01-043.info: A wet road surface has a negative effect on the behaviour of the disc brakes, the braking effect occurs later.
2.7.01-043.text: What particular characteristics of disc brakes must you remember when driving on a wet road surface?

2.7.01-045.asw_1: Load/Number of passengers in the car
2.7.01-045.info: If possible, the tyre pressure should be checked with cold tyres, as tyre pressure is influenced by temperature. The load/occupancy of the vehicle also has an effect. Because of this, the higher the cargo load, the higher the tyre pressure should be set.
2.7.01-045.text: What must you take into consideration when checking tyre pressure?

2.7.01-046.info: If the speed is doubled, the centrifugal force increases fourfold. The formula for the calculation is as follows: F = m x ((v x v) / r) (F = centrifugal force; m = vehicle mass; v = speed; r = curve radius)
2.7.01-046.text: You drive round a bend once at 30 km/h and again at 60 km/h. How does the centrifugal force change?

2.7.01-047.info: On the one hand, the strength of the centrifugal force depends on the speed. The higher the speed, the greater the centrifugal force. On the other hand, it depends on the curve radius. The tighter the curve, the higher the centrifugal force.
2.7.01-047.text: What increases the effect of centrifugal force on the vehicle when driving round bends?

2.7.01-102.asw_1: The distance for overtaking increases considerably
2.7.01-102.asw_2: Hasty movements of the steering wheel increase the danger of skidding
2.7.01-102.asw_3: The braking distance is reduced considerably
2.7.01-102.info: Caravan trailers react to hasty steering and threaten to break out. Due to the length of the train, the overtaking distance is longer. The additional weight and increased drag can further extend the overtaking distance.
2.7.01-102.text: What changes when a caravan trailer is towed?

2.7.01-103.asw_1: More space is needed when turning and driving round bends
2.7.01-103.info: The trailer leads to a higher total weight and increases air resistance, which reduces the capacity to accelerate. Due to the increased length, more space is needed in curves and thus also when turning, e.g., for the swing.
2.7.01-103.text: What changes in a car when towing a two-axle trailer?

2.7.01-104.asw_1: Think about the length of your car and trailer combination
2.7.01-104.asw_3: Warn oncoming traffic by flashing your lights
2.7.01-104.info: The trailer leads to a higher total weight and increases air resistance, which reduces the capacity to accelerate. Due to the increased length, more space is needed in curves and thus also when turning, also when overtaking. It also takes longer to cross the line of oncoming traffic.
2.7.01-104.text: You are in your car towing a trailer on a road with oncoming traffic and want to turn left. What must you particularly remember when you set off again?

2.7.01-105.asw_1: Reduce speed, if necessary, engage low gear in time, be ready to brake
2.7.01-105.asw_2: Make allowance for the pushing effect of the trailer
2.7.01-105.asw_3: Relieve the car brakes by disengaging the clutch at frequent intervals
2.7.01-105.info: On slopes, the trailer can develop a thrust effect, which must thus be taken into account. An adapted speed and a lower gear help to counter the effect of the thrust.
2.7.01-105.text: You are in your car towing a trailer which has no brakes and you approach a long steep downhill slope. What is correct?

2.7.01-107.asw_1: Whether the lights of the trailer are working
2.7.01-107.asw_2: Whether the view through the rear-view mirrors is adequate
2.7.01-107.asw_3: Whether the passengers in the caravan trailer have put on their safety belts
2.7.01-107.info: Before starting the journey, check that all the lights on the caravan are working. If the mirrors do not provide sufficient visibility, additional mirrors must be fitted.
2.7.01-107.text: What must you check on a car with a caravan trailer before setting out on a journey?

2.7.01-108.info: Due to the additional mass, the trailer provides a thrust effect that extends the braking distance.
2.7.01-108.text: You are in your car towing a fully loaded trailer which has no brakes. What is correct?

2.7.01-109.asw_1: If the permissible trailer load or the permissible coupling of the car are exceeded
2.7.01-109.asw_2: If additional rear-view mirrors must be mounted because of the width of the trailer
2.7.01-109.asw_3: If the trailer is licensed to transport passengers
2.7.01-109.info: Before towing a (residential) trailer, check that the permissible axle and drawbar load is not exceeded. The caravan could restrict the view through the mirrors. If this is the case, additional mirrors must be fitted.
2.7.01-109.text: You want to tow a singe-axle caravan trailer behind your car. What must you check?

2.7.01-110.asw_1: When selecting a gear, the car must, as a rule, be held by the service brakes
2.7.01-110.asw_2: The selector lever must only be moved when the engine has stopped
2.7.01-110.asw_3: The engine revolutions must be raised considerably so that the engine does not stall
2.7.01-110.info: As soon as the driving gear is engaged, the vehicle will start driving. This is why the gear selector lever can only be operated when the service brake is applied in most automatic vehicles.
2.7.01-110.text: You want to set off in an automatic car (hydraulic converter). What must you know?

2.7.01-111.asw_1: To check the air pressure regularly, including that of the spare wheel
2.7.01-111.asw_2: To increase the pressure to the level stated in the vehicle manual when the vehicle is heavily loaded
2.7.01-111.asw_3: To reduce the air pressure before longer trips
2.7.01-111.info: To avoid driving with too high or too low tyre pressure, the tyre pressure must be regularly checked – including the pressure of the spare wheel. A high cargo load requires a higher tyre pressure. It must be adjusted according to the vehicle manufacturer's specifications.
2.7.01-111.text: What must you remember with regard to tyre pressure?

2.7.01-112.asw_2: Driving longer than necessary with the emergency wheel
2.7.01-112.info: Due to their design, most emergency wheels may only be ridden at speeds of up to 80 km/h. The emergency wheel is not a permanent replacement. It may only be driven as far as absolutely necessary.
2.7.01-112.text: You had a tyre failure and must mount the emergency wheel. What is prohibited when you continue to drive?

2.7.01-115.asw_1: The rear end tends to turn out to the side
2.7.01-115.asw_2: The front end tends to turn out to the side
2.7.01-115.info: Cars with rear wheel drive tend to oversteer, i.e., the rear tends to turn out to the side if the motorist accelerates too much in a curve.
2.7.01-115.text: What does a rear-wheel drive car tend to do if you accelerate too much on a bend?

2.7.01-118.asw_2: Reduced danger of sliding sideways when setting off on a slippery roadway
2.7.01-118.asw_3: No locking of the wheels when braking
2.7.01-118.info: An anti-slip device (ASR) prevents the wheels from spinning when starting due to too much throttle. Even when starting off on a slippery road, more safety is offered and the risk of breaking out sideways is reduced.
2.7.01-118.text: What are the advantages of an anti-slip device (ASR)?

2.7.01-120.asw_1: The claw of the coupling must fit securely around the ball. The locking device must engage
2.7.01-120.asw_3: The jack wheel must be set so that it can also run when driving
2.7.01-120.info: A complete set-up of the hitch is essential to ensure a safe connection between the trailer and the vehicle. Such a connection can be recognized by the fact that the ball is engaged in the coupler. In addition, an electrical connection must be established. The signal lamps can only function if the trailer cable is plugged in.
2.7.01-120.text: You want to couple up a trailer with ball coupling. What is correct?

2.7.01-121.asw_1: Check that the brakes are working
2.7.01-121.asw_2: Raise the jack wheel, if fitted, to the highest setting
2.7.01-121.asw_3: Attach the brakeaway cable to the coupling of the motor vehicle
2.7.01-121.info: After coupling, the breakaway rope must be connected to the trailer coupling so that it releases the brake on the trailer in the event of an emergency. The function of the brake on the trailer must be checked in order to be able to safely participate in road traffic. The jack wheel should be moved to its uppermost position.
2.7.01-121.text: What must you do after coupling up a single-axle trailer with overrun brakes?

2.7.01-122.info: For safe operation, the permissible support load must not be exceeded. The same applies to the permissible axle load. The permissible total mass of the train must be taken into account, and exceeding it is not permitted.
2.7.01-122.text: What must you bear in mind when loading a single-axle trailer?

2.7.01-123.asw_2: Place wheel chocks under the wheels
2.7.01-123.info: Use the parking brake to secure the trailer against rolling away. Wheel chocks should be placed in front of the wheels to provide additional protection.
2.7.01-123.text: You want to park your single-axle trailer (overrun brakes, 1000 kg permissible total mass) on a slope. What must you do?

2.7.01-124.asw_1: The brakes may not work because of rust
2.7.01-124.asw_3: Tyre pressure may have increased greatly due to exposure to the sun
2.7.01-124.info: If it is not used for a longer period of time, brakes often tend to become rusty, which drastically reduces the braking effect. Cable connections may also be damaged, which means that the trailer lights no longer work.
2.7.01-124.text: Which dangerous defects can have occurred on a trailer with overrun brakes which has been parked for some time?

2.7.01-125.asw_2: - must not project more than 1 m beyond the rear reflectors, unless specially marked
2.7.01-125.asw_3: - must not project more than 1 m beyond the front of the towing vehicle
2.7.01-125.info: Other motorists must not be endangered. For this reason, the cargo must always be stowed safely. If there is no marking, the load must not extend more than 1 m beyond the reflectors.
2.7.01-125.text: What must you remember when loading a trailer?

2.7.01-127.asw_1: Because the braking action of the engine will have no effect
2.7.01-127.asw_2: Because this causes unnecessary wear of the brakes
2.7.01-127.asw_3: Because in this case the brake servo unit will no longer function
2.7.01-127.info: The engine provides a supportive braking effect when driving downhill. However, this is omitted when the clutch is pushed. As a result, the brakes have to be applied even more strongly, which increases their wear.
2.7.01-127.text: Why should you not apply the clutch when driving on a long, steep downhill slope?

2.7.02-015.info: The tread depth can be determined during tyre inspection. The same applies to whether the tread pattern is worn evenly. The age can also be read from the tyre.
2.7.02-015.text: What can you check on your tyre?

2.7.02-020.asw_1: When you drive a different vehicle
2.7.02-020.asw_2: If a vehicle has not been used for a longer period
2.7.02-020.asw_3: Each time the engine oil is changed
2.7.02-020.info: Different vehicles may be unfamiliar, including their braking behaviour. By means of an early brake test, an initial feeling for the brake system can be developed. After a prolonged standing time, there is a risk of reduced braking power, which must be detected in a timely manner.
2.7.02-020.text: In which cases is it imperative to test the brakes?

2.7.02-021.info: A regular check of the air pressure is necessary to avoid driving at too low a pressure. External damage should also be detected at an early stage, otherwise this could lead to tyre bursting. Regular checking of the tread pattern should ensure that the tyre does not fall below the minimum tread depth.
2.7.02-021.text: What do you have to check the tyres on your vehicle at regular intervals for?

2.7.02-027.asw_2: Because parts of the exhaust system can drop on the roadway
2.7.02-027.info: A rusted exhaust system generates unnecessary noise that can annoy other people. There is a risk that parts of the exhaust system may come loose and fall onto the road while driving, potentially endangering other motorists.
2.7.02-027.text: Why are you required to have a defective exhaust system repaired immediately?

2.7.02-028.info: An unusually loud exhaust may indicate a problem such as a defect due to wear. Consequently, the exhaust system should be checked.
2.7.02-028.text: The noise of the exhaust has suddenly become louder than usual. What do you do?

2.7.02-029.asw_2: The horn's operating device is defective
2.7.02-029.info: If the horn does not work, the control device or the contact on the steering wheel or handlebar may be defective. It is also possible that a fuse may have blown.
2.7.02-029.text: If the horn does not work, what can be the reason?

2.7.02-107.asw_1: Your car can veer to the side
2.7.02-107.info: If the brake acts strongly on one side, laterally acting centrifugal forces can occur that cause the vehicle to veer out. At the same time, the braking power is reduced, which increases the braking distance.
2.7.02-107.text: The brakes on your car are pulling strongly to one side. What effects can this have when you are braking?

2.7.02-109.asw_3: It is sufficient to fill up the brake fluid
2.7.02-109.info: There seems to be a serious defect in the brake system. Since safe participation in traffic is not possible in this way, the vehicle must be parked immediately. Then the defect must be professionally repaired.
2.7.02-109.text: When you press on the brake pedal, it touches the floor. Only when you press on it several times does the pedal travel become shorter. What must you do?

2.7.02-112.info: Defective brake lights impair safe participation in road traffic. Therefore, the lights must be repaired immediately.
2.7.02-112.text: The brake lights do not function. What do you do?

2.7.02-113.asw_1: The indicator signal light will flash faster than usual
2.7.02-113.asw_2: You cannot detect a defective indicator lamp while driving
2.7.02-113.info: If the light bulb of a flasher is defective, this is indicated by the indicator light flashing faster.
2.7.02-113.text: How can you tell while driving that an indicator lamp is not working?

2.7.02-114.asw_1: The headlamps on your vehicle are set incorrectly and are dazzling
2.7.02-114.asw_2: The light range adjustment is not adapted to your vehicle load
2.7.02-114.asw_3: Other drivers are telling you to turn on your main beam
2.7.02-114.info: The oncoming traffic seems to be dazzled. This may be caused by incorrectly adjusted headlights. It is also possible that the headlamp levelling control is set incorrectly or has not been adapted to the load condition.
2.7.02-114.text: You are driving in the dark with dipped headlights. Oncoming traffic flash their headlights at you. What can this mean?

2.7.02-115.asw_2: Do not renew the mirror glass because you can still partly see to the rear
2.7.02-115.info: The left outside mirror is essential for the driver and thus mandatory. Any damage must be repaired.
2.7.02-115.text: The glass in your left outside mirror is broken. What do you do?

2.7.02-117.info: If there is no water in the storage tank, the system cannot function. Clogged nozzles can also cause the windscreen washer system to malfunction. If the fuse is defective, the pump of the windscreen washer system does not work.
2.7.02-117.text: The windscreen washer does not work. What can be the reason for this?

2.7.02-118.asw_3: Too much water in the reservoir
2.7.02-118.info: Too little water indicates blocked nozzles of the windscreen washer system. It is also possible that the water feed pump is defective.
2.7.02-118.text: Too little water is coming out of the windscreen washer jets. What can cause this?

2.7.02-119.asw_1: The windscreen wiper blades are worn
2.7.02-119.asw_2: There is an oil film on the windscreen
2.7.02-119.info: A poor result is usually due to worn wiper blades. There may also be an oil film on the windscreen.
2.7.02-119.text: The windscreen wipers do not wipe clean? What can be the reason for this?

2.7.02-120.asw_3: Too much water in the windscreen washer
2.7.02-120.info: A possible cause of malfunctioning windscreen wipers may be a defective wiper motor. A blown fuse is another possible cause of malfunctioning windscreen wipers .
2.7.02-120.text: The windscreen wipers on your car do not function. What can be the cause of this?

2.7.02-121.asw_2: Nothing because the seat is equipped with an airbag
2.7.02-121.info: The seat belt must be able to be fastened and must also function in other ways. Therefore, a repair is absolutely necessary.
2.7.02-121.text: A safety belt lock does not close. What do you do?

2.7.02-125.info: Damaged suspension can lead to excessive tyre wear. The same applies to incorrect tyre pressure.
2.7.02-125.text: What can cause excessive wear on tyres?

2.7.06-101.asw_1: The vehicle is braked in the best possible way also on wet roadways
2.7.06-101.asw_2: Steering control is largely retained when braking
2.7.06-101.info: On slippery roads, ABS ensures that the wheels do not lock despite full braking and are thus braked as effectively as possible. Even with emergency braking, it is largely possible to continue to steer the vehicle.
2.7.06-101.text: What is the effect of an automatic anti-locking device (ABS)?

2.7.06-103.asw_1: The wheels do not lock when braking
2.7.06-103.asw_2: Steering control is retained even when braking heavily
2.7.06-103.asw_3: Bends can be taken considerably faster
2.7.06-103.info: ABS prevents the wheels from locking during braking. Even with emergency braking, it is largely possible to continue to steer the vehicle.
2.7.06-103.text: What are the advantages of an automatic anti-locking device (ABS)?

2.7.06-104.asw_1: It is possible to brake heavily and avoid an obstacle at the same time
2.7.06-104.asw_2: On setting off, wheelspin is prevented
2.7.06-104.asw_3: The danger of tipping over is reduced when braking on bends
2.7.06-104.info: On slippery roads, ABS ensures that the wheels do not lock and thus braking can occur in the best possible way. Even with emergency braking, it is largely possible to continue to steer the vehicle.
2.7.06-104.text: What are the advantages of an automatic anti-locking device (ABS)?

2.7.06-105.asw_1: When the trailer runs up to the truck
2.7.06-105.asw_2: When the brake pedal in the truck is activated
2.7.06-105.asw_3: Before the braking action of the truck starts, so that the truck and trailer remain extended
2.7.06-105.info: If the towing vehicle brakes, the mass inertia creates the possibility that the trailer may collide with the towing vehicle. With this, the trailer will start to brake, albeit somewhat delayed.
2.7.06-105.text: When does the braking action of a trailer with overrun brakes start?

2.8.01-001.info: The first time a driving licence is acquired, it is issued on a probationary basis. The probationary period is be two years from the date of issue.
2.8.01-001.text: What is the normal trial period?

2.2.03-018.info: The permissible speed for cars with trailers outside of built-up areas is 80 km/h.
2.2.03-018.text: What is the maximum speed you are allowed to drive a car with trailer on roads outside of built-up areas?

2.2.03-019.info:
The maximum authorised speed, even in the most favourable circumstances outside of built-up areas, is 80 km/h for

(a) motor vehicles with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3.5 tonnes but not exceeding 7.5 tonnes, excluding passenger cars;

(b) passenger cars with trailers,

(c) lorries and motor caravans, each up to a maximum authorised mass of 3.5 tonnes with trailers; and

(d) buses and coaches, with or without luggage trailers.
2.2.03-019.text: What is the maximum speed you are allowed to drive a truck with a 3.0 t gross vehicle weight rating with trailer on roads outside of settlements?

1.1.02-119.info: The child standing on the right between the parked vehicles may unexpectedly ride to the woman on the left side of the road. It is necessary to slow down to walking speed and to remain ready to brake.

1.1.02-121-M.asw_1: Wait to allow pedestrians to cross the road
1.1.02-121-M.asw_2: Continue driving, because there is sufficient time before the pedestrians have reached my side of the road
1.1.02-121-M.asw_3: Continue driving, because there are pedestrians on the left side of the road only
1.1.02-121-M.info:
Pedestrians seem to want to cross the lane at the zebra crossing and thus have priority - even if they are on the opposite side.

By braking early, you signal that pedestrians can enter the road.

1.1.02-122.asw_1: Pedestrians will step off the tram-stop island unheedingly
1.1.02-122.asw_2: Pedestrians will run across the road to the tram-stop island
1.1.02-122.asw_3: Pedestrians will wait until the road is clear
1.1.02-122.info: It is possible that pedestrians coming from the right will cross the road to get to the tram. Passengers getting off the bus from the left could also cross the road.
1.1.02-122.text: What actions should you anticipate at such stops?

1.1.02-123-M.asw_2: The pedestrian could let the truck pass by and then cross the road in front of me
1.1.02-123-M.asw_3: After the truck has taken the turn, pedestrians could approach from the opposite side of the road
1.1.02-123-M.info:
Because the truck is leaving the priority road and turning into another lane, it is likely that the truck will give way to the pedestrian.

It is also possible that the pedestrian will first let the truck pass and then cross the road.

The truck restricts visibility, which means that other vehicles on the road cannot be seen yet.
1.1.02-123-M.text: You want to turn right. What must you be prepared for?

1.1.02-124-M.info:
There are numerous pedestrians who could cross the road. The vehicles parked on both sides obstruct visibility, which means, for example, that pedestrians crossing the road can only be seen at a late stage.

Passengers could get out of the parked vehicles at any time and open the doors.
1.1.02-124-M.text: What must you be prepared for?

1.1.02-125-M.asw_1: That adults could walk onto the road
1.1.02-125-M.asw_2: That children could appear between the vehicles
1.1.02-125-M.asw_3: That it could be necessary to brake heavily
1.1.02-125-M.info:
Children could appear between the vehicles at any time - the traffic sign even explicitly warns of this danger. In addition to children, adults could also run onto the road.

Due to the densely parked vehicles, pedestrians and other motorists may only be visible at a late stage, so that heavy braking may be necessary at any time.

1.1.02-126.asw_1: They frequently have poorer sight and hearing
1.1.02-126.asw_2: They frequently react more slowly and are less mobile
1.1.02-126.asw_3: They frequently misjudge the speed of vehicles
1.1.02-126.info:
Reactivity and sensory perception decrease with increasing age. This is why older pedestrians often react more slowly and are less mobile.

They often misjudge the speeds of vehicles. Likewise, they may not see or hear as well.
1.1.02-126.text: Why are older pedestrians at more risk than younger ones from road traffic?

1.1.02-127.asw_1: That children playing run onto the road
1.1.02-127.asw_3: That all adults obey the road traffic regulations
1.1.02-127.info:
In residential areas with little traffic, there is an increased probability that motorists will underestimate the risks.

Therefore, cyclists and other motorists may be inattentive.

It cannot be ruled out that children may be playing near the road and possibly enter it.
1.1.02-127.text: What must you be aware of in residential areas with low traffic volumes?

1.1.02-128.asw_1: They will look neither left nor right
1.1.02-128.asw_2: They will unexpectedly walk onto the road
1.1.02-128.asw_3: Sometimes they turn back half-way across
1.1.02-128.info:
The behaviour of pedestrians is difficult to predict. Unlike motorists, they can turn around much more easily halfway across the road.

Some pedestrians rely exclusively on their hearing; therefore, they look neither to the left nor to the right. Pedestrians can enter the road unexpectedly at any time.
1.1.02-128.text: What actions should you anticipate from persons at the pedestrian crossing?

1.1.02-129.asw_1: - reduce speed and stop if necessary
1.1.02-129.asw_3: - continue driving at the same speed
1.1.02-129.info: White sticks serve as an orientation aid for people with visual impairments. Visually impaired people have much more difficulty assessing the traffic situation. Consideration must be shown, i.e., you must reduce your speed and stop if necessary.
1.1.02-129.text: A pedestrian with a white stick wants to cross the road in front of you. What should you do?

1.1.02-130-M.asw_1: That pedestrians will walk onto the road in front of me
1.1.02-130-M.asw_2: That children will suddenly appear between the vehicles
1.1.02-130-M.asw_3: That pedestrians will wait until I have driven past
1.1.02-130-M.info: The pavements are difficult to see due to the parked vehicles. Pedestrians could enter the road at any time. Children could also appear between the vehicles at any time. The traffic sign explicitly warns of this danger.

1.1.02-131.asw_1: That pedestrians will suddenly walk onto the road
1.1.02-131.asw_2: That doors of vehicles will be opened
1.1.02-131.info:
The pavements are difficult to see due to the parked vehicles. Pedestrians could enter the road at any time.

Likewise, people entering or leaving vehicles could open the doors at any time. Several vehicles could be approaching at any moment.

1.1.02-132.asw_1: The female pedestrian may walk unheedingly onto the road
1.1.02-132.asw_2: The pedestrian with the moped may change direction suddenly
1.1.02-132.asw_3: I can continue driving at the same speed
1.1.02-132.info: The pedestrian did not look back and thus did not keep an eye on the coming traffic. She could step onto the road at any time. The intention of the scooter driver is not clear; there is a risk that he may turn around or may suddenly cross the road.
1.1.02-132.text: What is your assessment of this situation?

1.1.02-133.asw_2: I am obliged to behave in a particular way towards this person
1.1.02-133.asw_3: This person belongs to a particular profession
1.1.02-133.info: The yellow armband indicates that the person is visually impaired. There is thus a special duty of conduct in traffic: increased consideration of this person.
1.1.02-133.text: A person at the side of the road is wearing a yellow armband with three black spots. What does this armband indicate?

1.1.03-116.asw_1: Because I might possibly not be able to stop in time, if pedestrians are crossing the side street
1.1.03-116.asw_2: Because vehicles emerging from the side street could start to skid
1.1.03-116.asw_3: Because my vehicle might start to skid if I take the turn too fast
1.1.03-116.info:
You are about to turn onto a road with a roadway that is obviously icy. Oncoming vehicles braking at the mouth of the intersection could skid.

Your own vehicle could also swerve or skid while turning the corner, so an appropriate speed is required. The slippery road also results in a longer braking distance.
1.1.03-116.text: Why might taking the right turn be dangerous here?

1.1.04-108.asw_1: Because persons on the road can be easily overlooked
1.1.04-108.asw_2: Because poorly lit vehicles can be difficult to detect
1.1.04-108.asw_3: Because oncoming vehicles will only be detected very late
1.1.04-108.info: Poor street lighting makes it easier to overlook people on the road. If vehicles are poorly lit, they are difficult to detect.
1.1.04-108.text: Why might driving along this road become dangerous?

1.1.04-110.asw_1: My eyes need to adjust to the change in lighting conditions
1.1.04-110.asw_2: Pedestrians frequently walk on vehicle lanes
1.1.04-110.asw_3: My tyres could get damaged by narrow entrances and exits
1.1.04-110.info:
In underground car parks, pedestrians are often on the vehicle lanes. Despite the lighting, it can be relatively dark in an underground car park compared to the previous environment, so that the eyes have to get used to the new lighting conditions first.

Narrow entrances and exits are not uncommon in underground garages. Tyres can be damaged by contact with kerbs or walls.
1.1.04-110.text: What must you watch out for when you drive into an underground car park?

1.1.05-103.asw_2: I may drive past the bus at walking speed
1.1.05-103.asw_3: I may not drive past the bus
1.1.05-103.info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.1.05-103.text: What must you be aware of?

1.1.06-122.asw_1: With the unsafe riding manner of the cyclist
1.1.06-122.info:
Due to the snow-covered road surface, a longer braking distance can be assumed. At the same time, there is an increased risk of slipping due to the winter road conditions.

The cyclist is also affected by the difficult conditions, which can result in unsafe riding.
1.1.06-122.text: What should you anticipate, if you want to overtake?

1.1.06-124.asw_2: I give a short warning signal before overtaking
1.1.06-124.asw_3: I overtake at a moderate speed
1.1.06-124.info:
Overtaking must not occur in this case, because overtaking requires sufficient lateral clearance from other motorists, in particular pedestrians and cyclists.

The person overtaking has to move back to the right as soon as possible. Motorists must not obstruct the vehicle that is to be overtaken.
1.1.06-124.text: You want to overtake cyclists on a narrow road. The width of the road means that the maximum possible space between them and the car is 50 cm. What should you do?

1.1.07-017.asw_1: - pull out and cross the centre of the road
1.1.07-017.asw_2: - brake and not cross the centre of the road
1.1.07-017.asw_3: - overtake without crossing the centre of the road
1.1.07-017.info: The oncoming driver wants to overtake the cyclist, which he has signalled. It is to be expected that he will pull out and drive over the dividing line in the middle of the road.
1.1.07-017.text: What should you anticipate in this situation?

1.1.07-020-M.asw_1: If I continue driving at the same speed
1.1.07-020-M.asw_2: If the cyclist changes to my lane
1.1.07-020-M.asw_3: If the cyclist stops at the end of the cycle path
1.1.07-020-M.info: The cycle path ends and at the same time turns into a footpath that may not be used by cyclists. The cyclist is likely to switch to the road. He may have to wait, but if he does not wait, there is a danger. Continuing to drive the car in a persistent manner may result in a collision if the cyclist does not stop.
1.1.07-020-M.text: When could a dangerous situation arise here?

1.1.07-136.asw_1: Slow down and be ready to brake
1.1.07-136.info: The reversing lights of the blue car signal that it could reverse and thus cut into the road. Therefore, it is important to reduce your own speed and to be ready to brake.

1.1.07-137.asw_1: Allow the cyclist to pass through the junction
1.1.07-137.asw_2: Check way is clear by glancing over your shoulder
1.1.07-137.asw_3: Take the turn ahead of the cyclist
1.1.07-137.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are riding or driving on or beside the road in the same direction. Because there might be another cyclist or motorist who cannot be seen in the mirror, looking over your shoulder is necessary.
1.1.07-137.text: You want to turn right. What should you do?

1.1.07-138.asw_1: The motorbike could swerve to the left
1.1.07-138.asw_2: The person beside the van could encroach further onto the road
1.1.07-138.asw_3: Pedestrians could cross the road in front of the van
1.1.07-138.info: The person beside the van could step backwards and thereby create a danger. The pedestrian could decide to cross the road in front of the transporter. It is to be expected that other pedestrians will enter the lane at any time or that vehicles that are standing still will start driving. This is why the motorcyclist could pull out.

1.1.07-139.asw_1: That the car continues to reverse
1.1.07-139.asw_2: That the motorbike will suddenly brake
1.1.07-139.asw_3: That my braking distance will be longer than normal
1.1.07-139.info: The car could continue to reverse because it wants to leave the parking space and enter the road. The motorcycle may have to brake suddenly because of the car. The braking distance could increase due to the winter road conditions.
1.1.07-139.text: Ahead of the motorbike a car is seeking to reverse on the road. What should you anticipate?

1.1.07-141.asw_1: Because I can be easily overlooked
1.1.07-141.asw_2: Because my speed can be underestimated
1.1.07-141.asw_3: Because I am at greater risk of injury in the event of an accident
1.1.07-141.info: In the event of an accident, motorists riding a two-wheeler have an increased risk of injury. Due to their compact dimensions, two-wheelers are overlooked more often in comparison to other motor vehicles. Because of their dimensions, the speed of two-wheelers is also often underestimated.
1.1.07-141.text: Why are you particularly at risk, if you are riding a two-wheeler?

1.1.07-142.asw_2: I reverse with my hazard lights turned on
1.1.07-142.asw_3: Driving a wide curve, I turn right
1.1.07-142.info: A safe change to the right lane is no longer possible. Remain in the lane and turn left.
1.1.07-142.text: Driving on a very busy road with several lanes, you have manoeuvred yourself into the lane for taking a left turn. Now instead of turning left, you want to turn right. What should you do?

1.1.07-143.asw_1: I should know how I park and leave my vehicle if I am unable to continue driving
1.1.07-143.asw_2: I should know how escape routes are indicated in tunnels
1.1.07-143.asw_3: I can be sure that help will arrive promptly in the event of emergencies
1.1.07-143.info: In the event of an accident, breakdown or any other dangerous situation, you need to know how and where you can park and leave the vehicle in the tunnel. It is important to know how escape routes are marked in the tunnel in order to move in the right direction in an emergency.
1.1.07-143.text: There is a tunnel on my route. What should I know?

1.1.07-144.asw_1: - turn on the hazard warning system
1.1.07-144.asw_3: - leave the key in the ignition
1.1.07-144.asw_pretext: I bring the vehicle to a halt as far to the right-side of the roadway as possible or park it in an emergency lay-by and
1.1.07-144.info: Switching off the engine reduces the risk of the vehicle moving in an uncontrolled manner. Switching on the hazard warning lights helps other motorists to recognise the potentially dangerous situation earlier. The ignition key remains in the ignition so that the engine can be restarted quickly if necessary.
1.1.07-144.text: While driving through a tunnel, you notice a fire in your vehicle. You are not able to exit the tunnel. What should you do?

1.1.07-145.asw_1: I trigger the fire alarm at the emergency call point
1.1.07-145.asw_2: I extinguish the fire as best I can
1.1.07-145.info: The fire alarm must be triggered so that the fire brigade and, if necessary, other rescuers can make their way to the area in danger. If the situation allows, try to extinguish the fire yourself. If this is not possible or if a lot of smoke develops, the tunnel must be exited via the nearest escape route.
1.1.07-145.text: While driving in a tunnel you were forced to bring your vehicle to a halt due to a fire. What should you do now?

1.2.01-003.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must show particular care towards children, the disabled and the elderly, in particular by reducing the speed of the vehicle and by being ready to brake.
1.2.01-003.text: To which road users must you show particular care?

1.2.02-106.info: If the line delimits a paved side strip, agricultural tractors and work vehicles, carts and similar slow vehicles (including mopeds) must drive as far to the right of the lane as possible.
1.2.02-106.text: When driving on main roads, which vehicles must use the hard shoulders where possible?

1.2.05-116.info: Drivers of slower vehicles must reduce their speed at a suitable place. If necessary, they should wait for several vehicles immediately following to overtake the slower vehicle if this is possible. Suitable side strips can also be used for this purpose. This doesn't apply to highways.
1.2.05-116.text: You are driving a slow-moving vehicle on a main road. How can you facilitate faster-moving vehicles in overtaking?

1.2.07-113.asw_1: - allow traffic on the terminating lane to merge in accordance with the alternate merging procedure
1.2.07-113.asw_2: - drive past the vehicles on the terminating lane
1.2.07-113.asw_3: - make eye-contact and then decide according to the situation
1.2.07-113.info: On roads with several lanes for one direction, if it is not possible to drive continuously on one lane or if one lane ends, the vehicles prevented from continuing should be allowed to pass over to the adjacent lane in such a way that these vehicles can alternate with a vehicle travelling on the continuous lane immediately before the narrowing begins (zipper feed-in method).
1.2.07-113.text: A lane terminates on a road with several lanes heading in the same direction. What should you do when driving on the through-lane?

1.2.09-119.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they drive on or beside the road in the same direction.
1.2.09-119.text: Why are you required to stop now?

1.2.09-120.asw_1: Observe traffic behind you, indicate the direction of turn, enter the lane
1.2.09-120.asw_2: Indicate the direction of turn, enter the lane, observe traffic behind you
1.2.09-120.asw_3: Enter the lane, indicate the direction of turn, observe traffic behind you
1.2.09-120.info: Before entering a lane and again before turning, pay attention to the traffic behind your vehicle. If you want to turn, you must indicate this clearly and in a timely manner by using the indicators.
1.2.09-120.text: You want to turn left. In what sequence do you prepare to take the left turn?

1.2.09-121.asw_1: I have to wait at the stop line
1.2.09-121.asw_2: I have to allow the cyclist to pass through
1.2.09-121.asw_3: I may make the turn in front of the cyclist
1.2.09-121.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction. Anyone driving a vehicle must stop at the stop sign and give way.
1.2.09-121.text: What is the right course of action?

1.2.09-123.asw_3: Pedestrians seeking to cross the road into which I am turning
1.2.09-123.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction. Special consideration must be given to pedestrians. If necessary, wait.
1.2.09-123.text: You want to turn left. To whom must you give priority?

1.2.09-124.asw_1: Visibility restrictions caused by oncoming vehicles
1.2.09-124.asw_2: Misunderstandings with oncoming traffic turning left
1.2.09-124.asw_3: Traffic turning left can come dangerously close
1.2.09-124.info: When turning left, misunderstandings with others turning left cannot be ruled out. It is possible that when you turn left, you will come very close to the oncoming traffic that is also turning left. Visibility restrictions due to oncoming traffic are possible.
1.2.09-124.text: You want to turn left. What difficulties could arise here?

1.2.10-104.asw_1: - allow pedestrians on the footpath to walk past
1.2.10-104.asw_2: - indicate the direction of movement prior to taking the turn
1.2.10-104.info: Anyone who wants to enter the road from a traffic-calmed area or approach from the edge of the road must behave in such a way that there is no danger to other motorists. The intention to enter the road or start the vehicle must be signalled clearly and in a timely manner by using the direction indicators.
1.2.10-104.text: You want to leave a traffic-calming zone and begin driving along a road. What should you do?

1.2.10-105.asw_3: Everyone is required to stop and then agree among one another who should proceed first
1.2.10-105.info: Anyone wishing to enter the road from a traffic-calmed area must behave in such a way as to avoid endangering other users of the road. Therefore, it is necessary for motorists to wait for cyclists.
1.2.10-105.text: You want to leave a traffic-calming zone and begin driving along a road. Cyclists are approaching from the left. Who is required to wait?

1.2.10-106.asw_3: Everyone is required to stop and then agree among one another who should proceed first
1.2.10-106.info: Anyone who wants to drive into the road from a property or from the edge of the road must behave in such a way that there is no danger to other users of the road. Therefore, it is necessary for motorists to wait for the cyclists.
1.2.10-106.text: You want to leave a property lot and turn right into a road. Cyclists are approaching from the left. Who is required to wait?

1.2.10-107.asw_1: Pedestrians on the footpath may not be endangered
1.2.10-107.asw_2: You should be directed by another person if necessary
1.2.10-107.asw_3: First take note of the flowing traffic on the road
1.2.10-107.info: Anyone who wants to drive onto the road from a property or from other parts of the road must behave in such a way that there is no danger to other users of the road. If necessary, you must let yourself be directed.
1.2.10-107.text: You want to leave a property lot and turn into a road while passing over a footpath. What must you look out for?

1.2.10-108.asw_1: I have to wait until the pedestrians have crossed over the exit
1.2.10-108.asw_2: I may drive on if the pedestrians waive their right of way
1.2.10-108.asw_3: I sound my horn briefly so that the pedestrians will allow me to exit
1.2.10-108.info: Anyone who wants to drive into the road from a property or from the edge of the road must behave in such a way that there is no danger to other users of the road. So we have to wait until the pedestrians have passed. If the pedestrians renounce their right of way, it is possible to drive on the road.
1.2.10-108.text: You want to exit the property lot. What is the right thing to do?

1.2.11-104.asw_1: Stop before the left turn and keep the central divide clear
1.2.11-104.asw_2: Turn smoothly, so as not to impede following traffic
1.2.11-104.asw_3: Come to a stop in the central divide, where the other car is stopped
1.2.11-104.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction. As a tram is approaching, you have to wait and keep the traffic island free.

1.2.11-105.info: Anyone who wants to overtake has to behave in such a way that there is no danger to the traffic behind his or her vehicle. When overtaking, sufficient lateral clearance must be maintained from other users of the road, in particular from pedestrians and cyclists. Because the cyclist is going to pull out, it is necessary to slow down and drive behind him.
1.2.11-105.text: What is the right course of action?

1.2.11-108.asw_1: If I would have to stop in the middle of the junction because the traffic is backing up
1.2.11-108.asw_2: If asked to stop by a police officer
1.2.11-108.asw_3: If the sign "Stop. Give way" is displayed at the junction
1.2.11-108.info: If there is traffic congestion, you must not drive into the intersection or junction despite the right of way or green light signal. The signs and instructions of police officers are to be followed. They take precedence over all other orders and other rules, but they do not release the motorist from the duty to pay attention.
1.2.11-108.text: In which situations are you not allowed to enter a junction even though the traffic light is green?

1.2.12-125.asw_2: On lanes marked with direction arrows
1.2.12-125.asw_3: In front of entrances to and exits from property lots
1.2.12-125.info: Stopping is not permitted on merging and demerging lanes. Anyone driving a vehicle is not allowed to stop on the part of the road that is marked with arrows.
1.2.12-125.text: Where is it forbidden to stop?

1.2.12-126-M.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must not stop on pedestrian crossings or up to 5 m in front of them.

1.2.19-112.info: If the red flashing light has the shape of an arrow, only those who want to drive in the direction of the arrow have to wait.
1.2.19-112.text: Who is required to stop at a level crossing with a red flashing light in the form of an arrow point to the right?

1.2.19-113.asw_1: - which I may approach at a maximum speed of 10 km/h
1.2.19-113.asw_2: - which I may cross at a maximum speed of 10 km/h
1.2.19-113.asw_3: - over which rail traffic may pass at a maximum speed of 10 km/h
1.2.19-113.info: The speed limit allows you to approach the level crossing at a maximum speed of 10 km/h. Because the limitation is valid until after the rail crossing, the crossing must be traversed with maximum 10 km/h.
1.2.19-113.text: What does this traffic sign combination indicate?

1.2.20-103.asw_1: - drive past maintaining sufficient space to the side
1.2.20-103.info: Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even in the event of oncoming traffic. When passengers are boarding or disembarking, vehicles may only pass on the right side at a walking speed and only at such a distance that there is no danger to passengers. They must also not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.2.20-103.text: You would like to drive past a local transport bus, which has come to a stop at a bus stop. What must you be aware of?

1.2.20-104.asw_1: That there is sufficient space to the side
1.2.20-104.info: Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even in the event of oncoming traffic. When passengers are boarding or disembarking, vehicles may only pass on the right side at a walking speed and only at such a distance that there is no danger to passengers. They must also not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
1.2.20-104.text: You are approaching a local transport bus, which has come to a stop at a bus stop. What must you watch out for when driving past it?

1.2.22-107.asw_2: - may not slide even when I brake
1.2.22-107.asw_3: - may never project over the front of the vehicle
1.2.22-107.info: The load must not interfere with the driver at any time. It must be so well secured that it does not slip even during an emergency stop.
1.2.22-107.text: What must you be aware of if you want to transport a load?

1.2.22-108.info: The load may not project in front of your verhicle if it is smaler than 2,50m. If this is not the case your load my project up to 50cm in front of your vehicle.
1.2.22-108.text: From what height it is permitted for loads to project up to 50 cm in front of your vehicle?

1.2.23-006.asw_1: I may be distracted by the call
1.2.23-006.asw_2: I may be distracted through operating the telephone
1.2.23-006.asw_3: Telephoning using a hands-free unit does not distract me
1.2.23-006.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may not use a mobile or car telephone if the mobile telephone or the handset of the car telephone must be picked up or held for this purpose. This does not apply if the vehicle is stationary and the engine is switched off in the case of motor vehicles. Operating the phone can distract you from the traffic. Even the conversation itself can be distracting.
1.2.23-006.text: You want to make a telephone call while driving a vehicle. What must you be aware of?

1.2.26-108.asw_1: Allow the pedestrians to cross the road
1.2.26-108.asw_2: Make the turn quickly before the pedestrians
1.2.26-108.asw_3: Warn the pedestrians by sounding the horn
1.2.26-108.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction. Special consideration must be given to pedestrians. If necessary, wait.
1.2.26-108.text: The traffic light is green. You want to turn right. How do you respond to pedestrians wishing to cross the road into which you want to turn?

1.2.26-109.asw_1: Allow the pedestrians to cross the road
1.2.26-109.asw_2: Make the turn quickly before the pedestrians
1.2.26-109.asw_3: Only wait if the pedestrians are using a marked crossing
1.2.26-109.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction. Special consideration must be given to pedestrians. If necessary, wait.
1.2.26-109.text: How do you respond to pedestrians wishing to cross the road into which you want to turn?

1.2.26-110-M.asw_1: Wait, because the two pedestrians have priority
1.2.26-110-M.asw_2: Continue driving, because the two pedestrians have to give way to me
1.2.26-110-M.asw_3: Proceed in front of the oncoming pedestrian, because he is required to wait
1.2.26-110-M.info: If you want to turn, you have to yield to oncoming vehicles, rail vehicles, electric bicycles and cyclists even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction. Special consideration must be given to pedestrians. If necessary, wait.
1.2.26-110-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.2.26-111.asw_1: If pedestrians want to cross the road
1.2.26-111.asw_2: If the view of the pedestrian crossing is restricted
1.2.26-111.asw_3: If another vehicle is already waiting at the pedestrian crossing
1.2.26-111.info: If another vehicle is already waiting at the pedestrian crossing, it is necessary to approach it carefully. If pedestrians wish to cross the crossing, they should approach at moderate speed or wait if necessary. A careful approach is also necessary in the event of limited visibility of the crosswalk.
1.2.26-111.text: In which instances do you have to approach a pedestrian crossing with particular care?

1.2.26-113.asw_3: I overtake the waiting vehicles taking extra care
1.2.26-113.info: At pedestrian crossings, vehicles, with the exception of rail vehicles, shall enable pedestrians and wheelchair users who wish to use the crossing in a recognisable manner to cross the carriageway. Then they may only approach at a moderate speed. If necessary, they must wait. Overtaking must not occur.
1.2.26-113.text: A pedestrian wants to cross the road via the pedestrian crossing. What should you do?

1.2.26-114.asw_1: I allow the pedestrian to cross the road
1.2.26-114.asw_2: I wait this side of the pedestrian crossing until the blue vehicle has made the turn
1.2.26-114.asw_3: I pull up directly behind the blue vehicle
1.2.26-114.info: At pedestrian crossings, vehicles, with the exception of rail vehicles, shall enable pedestrians and wheelchair users who wish to use the crossing in a recognisable manner to cross the carriageway. Then they may only approach with moderate speed. If necessary, they must wait. If traffic is at a standstill, vehicles may not drive onto the crosswalk if they would have to wait on it.
1.2.26-114.text: What should you do in this situation?

1.2.26-115.asw_1: In order that pedestrians are not unduly alarmed
1.2.26-115.asw_2: In order to avoid rear-end collisions
1.2.26-115.asw_3: In order that vehicles following behind can overtake more easily
1.2.26-115.info: Pedestrian crossings must be approached at a moderate speed. This way, the safety of pedestrians is not jeopardized. At the same time, the risk of a possible rear-end collision is reduced.
1.2.26-115.text: Why is it particularly important to adopt a defensive driving style when approaching pedestrian crossings?

1.2.26-116.asw_1: I approach at a moderate speed
1.2.26-116.asw_2: I give a warning signal and drive past the truck
1.2.26-116.info: The truck restricts the view of the pedestrian crossing. Therefore, it is necessary to approach the crossing at a moderate speed.
1.2.26-116.text: You are driving in the left-hand lane of a two-lane one-way street. About 30 m in front of you, a truck comes to a stop in the right-hand lane before a pedestrian crossing. What should you do?

1.2.26-117.asw_1: I allow the cyclist to cross the road
1.2.26-117.asw_2: I sound my horn and continue driving without giving way to the cyclist
1.2.26-117.asw_3: I only brake just short of the pedestrian crossing
1.2.26-117.info: Participation in road traffic requires constant caution and mutual respect. Anyone taking part in traffic must behave in such a way that no one else is harmed, endangered or harassed. Although or precisely because the cyclist would have to dismount, defensive behaviour is required, i.e., the cyclist must be allowed to pass.
1.2.26-117.text: A cyclist wishes - without dismounting - to cross the road at a pedestrian crossing. What should you do?

1.2.26-118.asw_1: Come to a stop before the pedestrian crossing to allow people to cross
1.2.26-118.asw_2: Wait on the pedestrian crossing if there is no-one in sight
1.2.26-118.asw_3: Wait on the pedestrian crossing to shorten the traffic jam
1.2.26-118.info: If traffic is at a standstill, vehicles must keep the crosswalk free of traffic.
1.2.26-118.text: In front of you is a pedestrian crossing, beyond which the traffic in your lane is backed up. What should you do?

1.2.34-110.asw_1: - move promptly to the side of the roadway if damage is minor
1.2.34-110.asw_2: - inform the other persons involved that I was also involved in the accident
1.2.34-110.asw_3: - provide my name and address upon demand to those entitled to this information
1.2.34-110.info: After a traffic accident, whoever is involved in it must stop immediately, secure the traffic and, in the event of minor damage, immediately drive to the side of the road. You must state that you have been involved in the accident and, on request, you must state your name and address, show your driving licence and registration document and give details of your civil liability insurance to the best of your knowledge.
1.2.34-110.text: You are involved in a traffic accident. What are you obliged to do?

1.2.34-111.asw_1: I turn on my hazard lights immediately
1.2.34-111.asw_2: I set up the warning triangle in a well-visible position about 100 m from the scene of the accident
1.2.34-111.asw_3: If necessary, I warn other vehicles, by using hand signals for example
1.2.34-111.info: If a multi-lane vehicle stops at a point where it cannot be detected in time as a stationary obstacle, hazard lights must be switched on immediately. Thereafter, at least one conspicuous warning sign shall be placed at a sufficient distance and in a clearly visible manner, about 100 m from the stopped vehicle. Prescribed safety measures, such as a warning triangle, shall be used. In addition, the regulations on the lighting of vehicles towing other vehicles apply. If necessary, other motorists must be warned, e.g., by hand signals.
1.2.34-111.text: You have an accident on a rural road. How do you secure the scene of the accident site?

1.2.37-012-M.info: The green arrow at the traffic light allows you to turn right.
1.2.37-012-M.text: What is correct in this situation?

1.2.37-013.info: Due to the speed and the short distance to the traffic light, it would be difficult to stop in time. Braking would be dangerous, especially because of the truck behind your vehicle.

1.2.37-015.asw_2: I must allow the oncoming traffic to pass through
1.2.37-015.asw_3: I have to wait in the centre of the junction
1.2.37-015.info: A green arrow to the left behind the intersection indicates that oncoming traffic is stopped at a red light and that if you turn left, you can enter and leave the intersection unhindered in the direction of the green arrow.
1.2.37-015.text: What is correct in this situation?

1.2.37-017.info: Due to the speed and distance to the traffic light, safe braking is possible. So we have to stop.

1.2.38-104.asw_1: I move out of the way immediately without endangering others
1.2.38-104.asw_2: I prompt the driver of the vehicle beside me to make way
1.2.38-104.asw_3: I make way immediately once the traffic light has turned green
1.2.38-104.info: An emergency vehicle with flashing lights is approaching. The blue light orders: "All other motorists must immediately clear the way". As long as there is no danger to other motorists, the vehicle may be driven further ahead even against a red light in order to enable the emergency vehicle to continue its journey.
1.2.38-104.text: You are being followed by an ambulance with its blue lights flashing and siren sounding. What should you do?

1.3.01-007-M.asw_1: I have to allow the cyclist to pass through
1.3.01-007-M.asw_2: I have to allow the motorcyclist to pass through
1.3.01-007-M.asw_3: I may make the turn before the cyclist
1.3.01-007-M.info: At this intersection, priority is given to those coming from the right. Therefore, the motorcyclist has priority. However, he must yield to the cyclist. The cyclist belongs to the oncoming traffic and thus has priority.
1.3.01-007-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-013-M.asw_1: I may be the first to pass through the junction
1.3.01-013-M.asw_2: I have to allow the red truck to turn
1.3.01-013-M.asw_3: I have to allow the cyclist to turn
1.3.01-013-M.info: At this intersection, priority is given to motorists coming from the right. The red truck has to wait. The same goes for the cyclist who, about to make a left-hand turn, must yield to oncoming traffic.
1.3.01-013-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-052.asw_1: I have to allow the cyclist to pass through
1.3.01-052.asw_2: I forgo my right of way so as to not block the junction
1.3.01-052.asw_3: I may turn left before the cyclist
1.3.01-052.info: The oncoming cyclist counts as oncoming traffic and thus has priority. Anyone who is otherwise allowed to continue driving according to the traffic rules or has priority elsewhere must refrain from proceeding if the traffic situation so requires. In this case, it is necessary to wait, because the lane is blocked by the stopped garbage vehicle.
1.3.01-052.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-112.asw_2: The blue vehicle has to wait
1.3.01-112.info: At crossroads and junctions, priority is given to those coming from the right. This does not apply to vehicles coming from a dirt road or forest road to another road.
1.3.01-112.text: You want to turn left. Who is required to wait?

1.3.01-113.info: The traffic sign "Grant right of way" regulates the right of way. There is an obligation to wait for the cyclist.
1.3.01-113.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-114-M.asw_1: I have to allow the cyclist to turn
1.3.01-114-M.asw_2: I have to allow the blue car to pass through
1.3.01-114-M.asw_3: The blue car has to allow me to turn
1.3.01-114-M.info: At this intersection, priority is given to those coming from the right. The cyclist may thus turn first. Priority must also be given to the blue car.
1.3.01-114-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-116.asw_1: I have to allow the cyclist to pass through
1.3.01-116.asw_2: I may make the turn in front of the cyclist
1.3.01-116.asw_3: The blue truck may proceed first
1.3.01-116.info: At this intersection, priority is given to those coming from the right. The blue truck thus must wait. First of all, the cyclist must be given priority, because if you want to turn, you have to let oncoming vehicles and cyclists pass through the intersection first, even if they are driving on or beside the road in the same direction.
1.3.01-116.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-117-M.info: Because of the STOP sign, you and the bus must stop at the stop line and give way to the cyclist. If you turn left, you have to wait and give way to the oncoming traffic – in this case, the bus.
1.3.01-117-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-118-M.asw_1: I have to allow the cyclist to pass through
1.3.01-118-M.asw_2: I may proceed before the motorcycle
1.3.01-118-M.asw_3: The cyclist has to allow me to pass
1.3.01-118-M.info: At this intersection, priority is given to those coming from the right. Therefore, the cyclist has priority. Afterwards, you can proceed, and the motorcyclist has to wait.
1.3.01-118-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.3.01-119.asw_1: I carefully ease my way into the junction
1.3.01-119.asw_2: I quickly cross over the junction
1.3.01-119.asw_3: I sound my horn to warn crossing traffic
1.3.01-119.info: Anyone who has to observe the right of way must make it clear that he or she will wait and make this clear in a timely manner by his or her driving behaviour, in particular by driving at a moderate speed. He or she may only continue driving if it is clear that the person who has the right of way will not be impeded. If this is not clear because the street section is unclear, he or she may carefully drive into the intersection or junction until the view is clear. Even if the person who has the right of way turns into the other road, the person obliged to wait must not obstruct the other motorist significantly.
1.3.01-119.text: You would like to cross over a priority road. The view to both sides is very restricted due to parked vehicles. What should you do?

1.3.01-120-M.asw_1: I have to allow the blue vehicle to pass
1.3.01-120-M.asw_2: I may make the turn before the green vehicle
1.3.01-120-M.asw_3: I have to allow the green vehicle to pass through
1.3.01-120-M.info: As you are wanting to turn left on the priority road, oncoming traffic – and thus the blue truck – must be given priority. Coming from the priority road, there is priority over the green car, so that the green car is obliged to wait.
1.3.01-120-M.text: What is the right course of action?

1.4.40-132.asw_1: - at a distance of approximately 240 m
1.4.40-132.asw_2: - at a distance of approximately 80 m
1.4.40-132.asw_3: - at a distance of approximately 160 m
1.4.40-132.info: The three-striped beacon indicates that there is a level crossing approx. 240 m away.
1.4.40-132.text: What does this traffic sign combination indicate?

1.4.40-135.asw_1: A rail crossing at a distance of 240 m
1.4.40-135.asw_3: A rail crossing at a distance of 120 m
1.4.40-135.info: The traffic sign combination warns of a level crossing in approx. 240 m distance. Overtaking is not permitted up to and including the intersection of rail and road.
1.4.40-135.text: What do you have to be aware of when you see this traffic sign combination?

1.4.40-136.asw_1: A work site, commencing at a distance of approximately 100 m
1.4.40-136.asw_2: A work site, ending at a distance of approximately 100 m
1.4.40-136.asw_3: A work site that is approximately 100 m in length
1.4.40-136.info: The danger sign warns of a construction site. The additional sign indicates the distance to the construction site, which is approx. 100 m.
1.4.40-136.text: What awaits you with this traffic sign combination?

1.4.40-142.info: The traffic sign indicates a level crossing.
1.4.40-142.text: What does this traffic sign combination indicate?

1.4.40-143.asw_1: You are nearing a hard right-hand bend
1.4.40-143.asw_2: Oncoming traffic might cut the corner
1.4.40-143.asw_3: Vehicles in front of me might slow down sharply
1.4.40-143.info: The traffic sign indicates a sharp right turn. It is possible that vehicles in front drive into the bend too fast and then suddenly brake sharply. From the point of view of oncoming traffic, this is a left-hand bend that may be cut.
1.4.40-143.text: What must you anticipate with this road sign?

1.4.40-144.asw_1: With cyclists who may cross the carriageway
1.4.40-144.info: The traffic sign indicates cyclists who are merging onto the road or crossing it, e.g., because a cycle path ends or crosses the road.
1.4.40-144.text: What must you anticipate with this road sign?

1.4.41-145.info: Cyclists may not use the road. Cyclists must use the cycle path. (There is an obligation to use the cycle path.)
1.4.41-145.text: What does this traffic sign indicate?

1.4.41-146.asw_pretext: 100 m ahead is a traffic sign saying
1.4.41-146.info: The traffic sign "Halt. Grant right of way" appears 100 m ahead.
1.4.41-146.text: What does this traffic sign combination indicate?

1.4.41-147.asw_2: A prohibition on cycles and mopeds
1.4.41-147.asw_3: The start of a traffic-calming zone
1.4.41-147.text: What does this traffic sign indicate?
